Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
R colon cancer
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Open right colectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to clinic with a diagnosis of right colon 
cancer diagnosed after she underwent a colonoscopy.  This was a 
large cecal cancer. Staging investigations demonstrated no 
metastatic disease.
She was offered a right colectomy.  She opted to proceed with 
open right colectomy.  Risks and benefits of the procedure were 
explained to the patient prior to proceeding the operating.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: DJD, sciatica, b/l blepharitis, diverticulosis, vit D 
deficiency, insomnia, HTN, HLD, LBBB, CKD III, vit B12 
deficiency

PSH: L knee arthroscopy
 
Social History:
Lives alone, but has daughter as support nearby.
 
Physical Exam:
Gen: AOx3, NAD, comfortable, pleasant
HEENT: anicteric sclera, EOMI OP clear with MMM
Resp: CTAB
CV: RRR S1S2
Abd: +BS, soft, minimally tender, non-distended, no masses
Wound: steristrips in place, c/d/i with no erythema, fluctuance 
or induration
Ext: WWP
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:38AM BLOOD WBC-7.9 RBC-3.14* Hgb-9.9* Hct-30.4* 
MCV-97 MCH-31.5 MCHC-32.5 RDW-12.8 Plt ___

___ 07:35AM BLOOD Calcium-7.8* Phos-1.8* Mg-2.3

PATHOLOGIC DIAGNOSIS:

Ileum, colon and appendix, ileocolectomy:

1. Mucinous adenocarcinoma invading into the muscularis propria 
(pT2, see synoptic report); the margins are negative for 
malignancy.
2. Sixteen lymph nodes with no malignancy identified ___, pN0, 
see synoptic report).
3. Colon with melanosis coli.
4. Unremarkable ileum and appendix.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on 
___ after an open right colectomy for colon cancer. The 
procedure went well without complication (reader referred to the 
Operative Note for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in 
the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor.
 
Neuro: The patient had an epidural which was transitioned to  
oral pain medications on POD2 with good effect and adequate pain 
control.  
Cardiopulmonary: The patient remained stable from a 
cardiopulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely 
monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and incentive 
spirrometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization.
GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO with IV 
fluids. Diet was advanced when appropriate, which was well 
tolerated.  Patient's intake and output were closely monitored, 
and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary.  Electrolytes were 
routinely followed, and repleted when necessary.
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection.  The wound dressings were monitored daily.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.
 
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. She was evaluated by physical therapy and after 
discussion with the patient, family, and ___, she was discharged 
home with home ___. The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.

eye

heartburn

every 6 hours Disp #*20 Tablet Refills:*0

eye

eyes

16. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
Please take while taking Ultram. 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right colon cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the general surgery inpatient service after 
your surgery. You are now stable enough to continue your 
recovery at home. 

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed. Avoid driving or operating 
heavy machinery while taking pain medications. 

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Please continue 
drinking Ensures while at home to make sure you keep up with 
your calories.  Avoid lifting weights greater than ___ lbs 
until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct you 
further regarding activity restrictions.
  
Please follow-up with your surgeon as advised.
 
Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water.  Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own.  
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

It was a pleasure taking care of you!
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ CT Torso: Grade 5 liver lac extending to IVC, Grade 2 right 
renal lac at lower pole, Bilateral rib fx, L clavicular fx, R 
pulm contusion/aspiration bilaterally, L L2 transverse process 
fx
Small area of stranding/fluid around transverse colon. No free 
air, stable between scans
___ CT Abd/pelvis: no new fluid collection
___ CT abd: No acute pathology including no bowel obstruction 
or abscess. Stable liver and renal lacerations. Decreased amount 
of high-density fluid in the pelvis.Small bilateral pleural 
effusions and atelectasis. 
ERCP: Normal major papilla. Clear bile seen. Common bile duct, 
common hepatic duct, R+L hepatic ducts, biliary radicles + 
cystic duct filled with contrast, well visualized. Normal w/o 
evidence of extrinsic compression, no ductal abnormalities, and 
no filling defects.
___ ERCP:Normal major papilla. Clear bile seen at the major 
papilla and in the duodenum. The common bile duct, common 
hepatic duct, right and left hepatic ducts, biliary radicles and 
cystic duct were filled with contrast and well visualized. 
The course and caliber of the structures are normal with no 
evidence of extrinsic compression, no ductal abnormalities, and 
no filling defects.  
___ KUB: No evidence of bowel obstruction or ileus.
___ b/l ___ US: Negative for DVT.  Loculated ___ cyst.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ Pt admitted to the trauma surgical service s/p Motor cycle 
crash with positive loss of consciousness. Injuries included 
Grade 4 liver lac extending to IVC  
Grade 2 right renal lac at lower pole; Bilateral rib fx; L 
clavicular fx  ; R pulm contusion/aspiration bilaterally ; L L2 
transverse process fx  ; Small area of stranding/fluid around 
transverse colon. No free air, stable between scans.  ___ 
admitted to the TICU for observation. 
___: ___ remianed in TICU.  Acute pain service consulted for 
pain managment with bupivicaine 0.1 ___ and diluadid pca ___: Epidural IV PCA, MS ___ 15 mg po TID  
___: Epidural continued; stopped PCA; MS ___ and MSIR  PO 
meds started.
___: + ambulation w/ ___.  CT Abd/pelvis follow up examination 
performed.
___: capped and flagged epidural; foley removed with 
positive void. Aggressive bowel regimen started.  
___: Pt noted to have increased abdominal pain in the p.m. KUB 
demonstrated ileus. Foley reinserted due to incomplete voiding 
and post void residuals of 388 cc.
___ CT abd performed for continued abdominal discomfort: No 
acute pathology including no bowel obstruction.    
___ Increased LFTs and abdominal pain prompted r/o for biliary 
injury with ERCP.  ___ kept NPO  for procedure.
___ performed- normal exam.  F/u amylase and lipase not 
acutely elevated, no evidence of pancreatitis.
___ KUB: No evidence of bowel obstruction or ileus.  Pain in R 
leg with area of hardness prompted  b/l ___ US: Negative for DVT. 
 Loculated ___ cyst. Pt tolerating a regular diet.  Pain 
well controlled with PO pain meds.   Pt ambulating and cleared 
by ___.  Pt with large BM.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p Motorcycle crash
Right pulmonary contusion
Left clavicle fracture
Bilateral rib fractures
Grade II right renal laceration
Grade V liver laceration
Left L2 transverse process fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Hemodynamically stable, tolerating a regular diet, pain 
adequately controlled

 
Discharge Instructions:
It is important that you cough, deep breathe and use the 
incentive spirometer every hour that you are awake.

DO NOT participate in any contact sports of any kind for the 
next 8 weeks because of your liver injury.

If at any time you feel dizzy, weak and/or lightheaded, as if 
you are going to pass out you will needto go to the nearest 
Emergency room as this may be a sign that you may be 
experiencing internal bleeding from your liver.
Return to the Emergency room if you develop any fevers, chills, 
increased productive cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, 
abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and/or any other 
symptoms that are concerning to you.

It is important that you take the pain medications as 
prescribed. A stool softener and laxative have been prescribed 
for you; it is important that you take these while on narcotics 
in order to prevent constipation.

Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
___ s/p unwitnessed fall, unresponsive, with multiple L rib 
fractures and pneumothorax
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Intubated in the ED secondary to agitation and emesis 
with aspiration
___: Placement L chest tube in ED, later removed as it was 
found to be in subcutaneous space.
___: Arterial line placed
___: Insertion left-sided 3-lumen subclavian CVL
___: Percutaneous tracheostomy at ICU bedside for failure to 
wean from vent
 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ with a hx of alcohol dependence who was found down 
and unresposive by his wife after apparently ___ down 8 
concrete steps.  The pt was initially oriented x1 with a GCS of 
4 on the scene, however his GCS was 15 in the ED.  He became 
agitated in the ED, vomited, and desaturated and was therefore 
intubated for airway protection.  CT in the ED showed left sixth 
through ninth rib fractures and a small left-sided pneumothorax.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: CAD, peripheral neuropathy, depression, gout, EtOH 
dependence, asbestosis/lung scar
PSH: CABG, aortic valve (tissue) replacement ___

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
HR:75 BP:118/62 Resp:22 O(2)Sat:93 nrb low 
 
Constitutional: Moaning, uncomfortable, confused
HEENT: Pupils equal, round and reactive to light, Extraocular 
muscles intact, C-collar, no crepitus
Chest: Clear to auscultation, + L chest wall ttp
Cardiovascular: Regular Rate and Rhythm
Abdominal: Soft, diffuse ttp, R inguinal hernia easily 
reducible, FAST negative, stable pelvis
Extr/Back: c/o diffuse pain with vertebral palpation
Skin: R lateral thigh ecchymosis, R knee laceration, L arm 
abrasion
Neuro: Confused, follows commands, MAE, equal strength 
bilaterally, decreased sensation to l.t. in bilateral feet(which 
patient states is old)

 
Pertinent Results:
___ CT A/P: Mildly displaced multilevel left-sided rib 
fractures. At the site of rib fractures there is a chest tube, 
which does not enter into the thoracic cavity. There is 
subcutaneous emphysema with a small amount of hematoma at this 
site.  Small left basilar and apical pneumothorax.  Bibasilar 
atelectasis. Pleural calcifications may reflect asbestos 
exposure, correlate clinically. 

___ CT C-Spine: No fracture of the cervical spine. Compression 
deformity at T2 age-indeterminate but may relate to degenerative 
changes. Degenerative changes at C3-4 and C4-5 cause mild degree 
of central canal 
narrowing may predispose to cord injury in the setting of 
trauma. If there is concern for cord injury, MRI would be 
recommended. Left apical pneumothorax, seen on concurrent CT 
Torso. Patient is intubated. Nasogastric tube in the esophagus. 

___ CT Head: . No acute intracranial findings. Parenchymal 
atrophy and small vessel disease. 

___ TLS-Spine MRI: No evidence of acute fractures. Compression 
fractures involving T2, T5 and L1 are likely chronic given 
absence of marrow edema.  Mild multilevel degenerative changes 
as described above with multiple 
areas of mild to moderate foraminal stenosis and mild cord 
indentation at 
T5-T6 without cord signal intensity abnormality. 
Well-circumscribed 2-cm upper back subcutaneous lesion, most 
consistent with an epidermal inclusion cyst or a sebaceous cyst. 
Minimal marrow edema L2 and L3 and L5-S1 facets and C1-2 lateral 
mass joints , pattern most compatible with degenertive changes 
without secondary features to indicate acute trauma. Multilevel 
degenerative changes as described above. 

___ CXR: Asymmetric lucency of the left lung suggests an 
anterior pneumothorax in this supine patient. Right lower lobe 
opacity likely reflects new right pleural effusion (moderate) 
and right lower lobe consolidation. New moderately severe 
pulmonary edema. 

___ CT Chest: Bilateral moderate-sized simple pleural effusions 
and associated compressive atelectasis of the lower lobes, new 
since the prior study. Multifocal ground-glass opacities in the 
right lung may represent 
infection or aspiration. Extensive subcutaneous emphysema in the 
left anterior chest wall, has increased since the prior study. 
Interval resolution of a left-sided pneumothorax. Multiple left 
recent rib fractures and non-acute right rib fractures. 

___ CXR:  The Dobbhoff catheter is in the left main bronchus 
and should be removed. Stable severe right lower lobe pneumonia, 
bilateral pleural effusions and left lower lobe atelectasis.  

___ CXR: The Dobbhoff tube is coiled in the stomach. The tip 
projects over the middle parts of the stomach. Normal 
tracheostomy tube. No evidence of complications. Unchanged left 
subclavian vein catheter. Mild retrocardiac atelectasis. 
Unchanged size of the cardiac silhouette. The study and the 
report were reviewed by the staff radiologist. 

___ CXR: Improved ventilation at both lung bases with small 
remnant areas of atelectasis. No newly-occurred focal 
parenchymal opacities. Mild 
cardiomegaly without pulmonary edema. 

___ CXR: As compared to the previous radiograph, the Dobbhoff 
tube has been advanced. The tip of the tube now projects over 
the middle parts of the stomach. No evidence of complications. 
Otherwise, the radiograph is 
unchanged.

Brief Hospital Course:
Neuro:  The patient requires medication for agitation, and 
should continue oxycodone and Tylenol prn pain, as well as 
clonidine, seroquel QHS, q16:00 and prn.  Zyprexa Zydis was used 
prn as well.  For his history of EtOH dependence and previous 
episodes of complicated withdrawal he was maintained on CIWA 
protocol with thiamine, folate & multivitamin for 
neuroprotection. Benzodiazepines were stopped ___.  He has been 
in restraints intermittently for agitation and pulling at lines.

CV: The pt was initally in septic shock from his pneumonia and 
required pressors to mainatin hemodynamic stability.  These were 
discontinued on ___.  The pt has been maintained on metoprolol 
25 mg BID

Pulm: The pt was initially intubated in the Emergency Department 
for agitation, emesis and concern for aspiration.  He was found 
to have a leftsided pneumothorax and a chest tube was placed in 
the ED.  This was found to enter the subcutaneous space and was 
removed.  The pneumothorax did resolve on serial films.  The pt 
did develop a likely aspiration pneumonia and was treated 
empirically with Vancomycin and Zosyn, and completed a 10-day 
course on ___.  The pt was unable to wean from the vent and was 
very agitated by the ETT tube, a bedside percutaneous 
tracheostomy was performed in the ICU ___ with a #8 Portex.  He 
has been able to wean to CPAP and, on the day of discharge did 
have a trial with trach mask.

FEN/GI: Pt had dobhoff tube placed x3 for tube feeds.  He pulled 
out the first two and the third was carefully secured with tape. 
 Tube feeds were initiated per Nutrition recommendations and, at 
time of discharge, were running at goal (55cc/hr).

ID: The pt was initially septic from his pnemonia and completed 
a 10-day course of Vanc/Zosyn on ___, pressors d/c'ed ___.

GU: The pt has been diuresed with Lasix 20mg IV BID. He has a 
Foley catheter.

Musculoskeletal: Pt has lateral L rib fractures of ___.  He also 
has old compression deformities of T2, T5, L1.  He came off 
logroll precautions and had his C-Spine cleared ___.

Heme: Heparin SC and venodyne boots for DVT Prophylaxis, PPI for 
ulcer prophylaxis

 
Medications on Admission:
zocor, ASA, omeprazole, allopurinol, ativan, neurontin, atenolol

Instructons for NPO Patients: Evening Prior to 
Surgery/Procedure: If on glargine or detemir: give 80% of usual 
dose; If on NPH: give 100% usual dose. Morning of 
Surgery/Procedure: If on glargine or detemir: give 80% of usual 
dose; If on NPH: give 50% of usual dose; If on premix insulin 
(e.g. 70/30, 75/25): take total number of AM units ordered, 
divide by 3, and give that many units as NPH; If on sliding 
scale of short acting insulin: administer according to HS 
schedule. Hold all oral antidiabetic medications, and consider

Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.
Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

Brief Hospital Course:
#. Pelvic fracture. He was initially admitted to the trauma 
surgery service.  He was seen by orthopedic surgery and a pin 
was placed through the distal femur and the leg was placed in 
traction in anticipation of possible surgery.  3d reconstructive 
CT imaging of the pelvis was performed.  Ultimately, it was 
decided to treat this fracture non operatively given his 
baseline functional status and the severity of his fracture on 
imaging.  The pin was removed. Pain was controlled with IV 
morphine and PO oxycodone.

# Retroperitoneal Bleed.  On CT, retroperitoneal and pelvic 
bleeding was discovered. Interventional radiology was consulted 
and patient was monitored clinically.  He remained 
hemodynamically stable and his hematocrit remained stable and no 
intervention was necessary. His hematocrit remained stable for 
the remainder of his hospitalization.

# Hospital Acquired Pneumonia - On ___, patient developed a 
fever, hypoxia and an infiltrate was noted on CXR.  He was 
started on empiric therapy for hospital acquired pneumonia of 
vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and cefepime IV.  A 7 day course was 
completed with an improvement in his breathing, and a reduction 
in his oxygen requirement.  On the floor he was given standing 
albuterol and Atrovent nebs, and was had regular chest ___ with 
respiratory therapy with a significant improvement in function.  


# Tachycardia - Patient had tachycardia, alternating between 
sinus tachycardia and multifocal atrial tachycardia in the range 
of 110-140 early in his SICU course.  Cardiology was consulted 
and recommended up titration of his metoprolol. His metoprolol 
was gradually up titrated to 200mg PO tid.  As his clinical 
picture improved, this dose was gradually reduced to 50mg PO 
bid, with rates in the ___ on discharge.

# Nutrition - Initial speech and swallow evaluation found that 
it was unsafe for him to take anything PO due to aspiration 
risk. A Dobbhoff feeding tube was placed for nutrition and given 
tube feeds.  He pulled the feeding tube once, and it needed to 
be replaced.  Repeat speech/swallow evaluation with video 
swallow found him to be safe to eat pureed solids with nectar 
thickened liquids.  Feeding tube was removed and he was started 
on the recommended diet on discharge.

#. Goals of care - The patient had severe dementia, and had no 
health care proxy on admission.  Guardianship was obtained 
emergently given the patient initially tenuous clinical status.  
___ (___ has agreed to be Mr. ___ guardian.  On 
discussion with Mr. ___ tube placement was declined 
and it was decided to change Mr. ___ code status to 
DNR/DNI.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was transferred to ___ Emergency Department on 
___ from an outside hospital. Mr. ___ was evaluated by 
the acure care surgery team. Initial imaging (CT Abdomen ___ 
identified multiple rib fractures and small to moderate left 
pneumothorax and a grade 2 splenic laceration. ( 1. No 
suspicious arterially-enhancing liver lesions are identified.  
2. Unchanged sequela of liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension, 
including splenomegaly, paraesophageal, and splenic varices.  3. 
Cholelithiasis without cholecystitis.)  A same day CXR ___ 
showed again, multiple left rib fractures and small to moderate 
left pneumothorax. and layering left hemothorax. CT head and 
C-spine were negative. 

Given concern for continued hemopneumothorax, a left sided chest 
tube was placed on ___ and 200cc drained immediately, with an 
additional 800cc afterwards. Platelets were transfused prior to 
chest tube placement. The patient was restarted on his home 
rifaximin and lactulose. Home spironolactone held for 
hyperkalemia. The Acute Pain Service (APS) was consulted for an 
epidural, however the patient was deemed to not be a good 
candidate given the thromboyctopenia. Serial hematocrits 
stabilized: 40->35->36.8->35.6->33.1->33.1. Adjuncts were added 
for pain control: APAP ATC (cleared with hematology service 
given the history of liver disease) and additional pain control 
was achieved with a dilaudid PCA and lidocaine patch. The diet 
was advanced to clears and then ADAT regular. The patient was 
placed in the trauma surgical intensive care unit and a tertiary 
trauma survery was remarkable for shoulder pain. Plain films of 
shoulder were negative. The next day the patient was 
transitioned to po oxycodone, the dPCA was discontinued. 
However, the pain was poorly controlled and other adjuncts were 
adjusted: gabapentin increased, clonidine started, dilaudid 
PRNs. The chest tubes were placed to water seal and home BP 
medications were restarted. On ___, additional pain control 
was required and oxycodone was increased per APS.  The ___ CXR 
looked worse and CT was put back to suction. The patient was 
stable and transfered to the surgical care floor. The ___ CXR 
showed a persistence of PTX and thus the chest tube was kept on 
suction. Patient was demonstrating good respiratory excursion 
and using IS well. Physical therapy was consulted and 
recommended discharge to home when medically ready. 

On ___, repeat CXR continued to show a PTX and CT was kept on 
suction. Over the course of the next few days CXR imaging 
continued to show a persistent left sided apical PTX with small 
left costophrenic angle blunting. However the patient continued 
to remain afebrile, with increasingly better pain control, and 
continued to not experience any respiratory distress. On ___ 
CT output decreased to approximately less than 200cc/day and the 
CT was placed on water seal. On ___ CXR showed an unchanged 
apical PTX and the CT was pulled with stable post-pull CXR. On 
___ CXR again showed a stable PTX and Mr. ___ was 
prepared for discharge to home with close follow up with CXR 
imaging arranged. 

The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ dyne boots 
were used during this stay and was encouraged to get up and 
ambulate as early as possible. At the time of discharge, the 
patient was doing well, afebrile and hemodynamically stable.  
The patient was tolerating a diet, ambulating, voiding without 
assistance, and pain was well controlled.  The patient received 
discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding 
verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,
You were brought to the ___ ED after sustaining a fall from a 
ladder. You were found to have rib fractures, a collapses lung 
and a laceration of your spleen. You have recovered and are now 
ready to be discharged from the hospital.

Please read the following instructions:
*AVOID contact sports and/or any activity that may cause injury 
to your abdominal area for the next ___ weeks.
 
*If you suddenly become dizzy, lightheaded, feeling as if you 
are going to pass out go to the nearest Emergency Room as this 
could be a sign that you are having internal bleeding from your 
liver or spleen injury.
 
*AVOID any blood thinners such as Motrin, Naprosyn, Indocin, 
Aspirin, Coumadin or Plavix for at least ___ days unless 
otherwise instructed by the MD/NP/PA.

* Your injury caused multiple rib fractures which can cause 
severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths 
because of the pain.
 
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.
 
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.
 
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.
 
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.
 
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.
 
* Do NOT smoke
 
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
 
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).

___ today.  Bone scan results discussed with her from
___.  We see a lot of increased tracer around the total
knee prosthesis on both the femoral and the tibial component,
more on the tibia.  This is consistent with
infection/osteomyelitis since we are picking up tracer on all
three phases of the scan.  As I noted in my prior visits,
aspiration of the knee fluid has been benign in final culture
results and in the number of white blood cells but that 
certainly
cannot rule out osteomyelitis of the bone, which would be
subsynovial.  Given her persistent pain, the number of surgeries
she has been through, the progressive radiolucency seen on plain
film and now with the bone scan, we are going to move forward
with a two-stage resection arthroplasty.  We will remove her
entire prosthesis.  Because she is quite stiff and has had the
prior osteotomy of the tibial tubercle with translocation and 
has
retained hardware including some broken hardware quite possibly
at surgery, need to take down the osteotomy, remove the 
hardware,
remove all the implants, and freshen up the tibial osteotomy 
site
for a reimplantation at the time she has her total knee
replacement 8 weeks later after interim antibiotic spacer and IV
antibiotics.  Even if she comes back with negative culture on 
the
multiple tibia cultures, I probably would still want to treat 
her
long six weeks with antibiotics since there is a high suspicion
that there is infection even though it is to date eliminated,
determination/detection.  ___ understands it we cannot
guarantee that she will have a pain free knee.  It is quite
possible that she will always have trouble with this knee.  She
has arthrofibrosis now and that certainly may be a problem 
later.
Longevity of implants in the setting of prior osteomyelitis
presumptive is hard to establish.  She will not be able to
weightbear on this extremity for 8 weeks until it is
re-implanted.  She does understand and will try and maintain 
some
amount of range of motion through the knee, but I do not think
she would be a great benefit for her to have a hinged type 
insert
since.  We are able to maintain nearly as much motion with a
custom antibiotic spacer.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old-woman with a history of 
relapsed/refractory AML, s/p multiple failed therapies including 
allogenic stem cell transplant in ___, most recently 
on cabozatinib as part of DF/HCC Protocol ___: Phase 1 trial 
of cabozantinib in patients with relapsed or refractory AML. She 
presented with leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, fatigue, anorexia 
and weakness and was found to have toxicity from cabozatinib. 
Her hospital course was complicated by aspergillus pneumonia and 
colitis.

# AML/Leukocytosis
Upon admission, the patient was treated with hydroxyurea with 
good response, and it was discontinued on ___ when her WBC 
reached 6.1. However, her white count continued to decrease and 
remained below 1.0 until discharge. Upon admission, she had 
elevated LFTs with ALT 99, AST 92, LDH 863, and AlkPhos 171. 
They continued to trend up with a peak on ___ of ALT 85, AST 
153, and AlkPhos 145. Subsequently, her total bilirubin trended 
up to 3.8 on ___. The changes were thought to be due to 
carbozatinib toxicity, and she was removed from the study. Her 
LFTs subsequently normalized by discharge. She received a repeat 
bone marrow biopsy on ___, which the full report is pending at 
discharge.

# Febrile Neutropenia
She became febrile early in the morning on ___ while 
neutropenic. She was started on cefepime and vancomycin. Blood 
cultures eventually showed no growth. Patient was found to have 
colitis by abdominal CT on ___. Cdiff was negative. She was 
switched from cefepime to meropenem until discharge, at which 
time she was sent home with ciprofloxacin for bacterial 
prophylaxis and 5 days of metronidazole. She became afebrile on 
___ and remained afebrile until discharge.

# Hemoptysis / Aspergillus Pneumonia
The patient reported hemoptysis, and ENT was consulted on ___. 
They determined that the source of bleeding was most likely 
mucosal given thrombocytopenia as they noted clotted blood at 
the back of the right nostril, however, the scope was limited 
and they could not see superiorly with the equipment. A CT chest 
on ___, however, showed cavitations and nodules, which were 
concerning for aspergillosis. Given that she had a history of 
aspergillosis with hemoptysis, she was started on ambisome 
initially for treatment with elevated bilirubin. Once the 
bilirubin normalized, she was given voriconazole until 
discharge.

# Thrombocytopenia
She had thrombocytopenia, which was likely secondary to her AML. 
She was consistently transfusion dependent and required frequent 
platelet transfusions. She had some gingival bleeding that 
resolved by the time of discharge.

Mr. ___ is a ___ with PMH T1DM, alcohol/IVDU abuse (sober x 
15 months), and hepatitis C who presented from outside hospital 
in ___.  Four days prior to admission, Pt had 
malaise/myalgias/nausea/vomiting that he thought was a stomach 
bug.  As he wasn't able to eat, Pt stopped taking his insulin.  
Two days prior to admission he became increasingly fatigued and 
shaky, which led him to present to ___.  Pt was started on 
insulin gtt and then transferred to ___.  

=================
___ ICU COURSE
=================
Pt was maintained on an insulin drip until his anion gap closed 
and he was able to tolerate PO, at which point he was 
transitioned to injectable insulin.  Also given brisk IV 
hydration and repletion of his hypokalemia/hypophosphatemia.  

# T1DM with # DKA:  Likely precipitated by nonadherence to 
insulin egimen in setting of GI illness.  No obvious infectious 
source on CXR or UA.  Put on insulin gtt, fluid repleted with ___ NS with K.  Transitioned to subq insulin hen anion gap 
closed.  ___ was consulted, and titrated Pt's insulin 
throughout his course. 

# NAUSEA/VOMITING:  DDx viral gastroenteritis vs. manifestation 
of Pt's DKA.  Had a borderline prolonged QTc on admission (see 
below), so antiemetics used sparingly during his course.  N/V 
improved as glycemic control improved.

# PROLONGED QTc:  No medications or drugs on board that could 
obviously prolong QTc.  Repeat EKG demonstrated QTc of 432.  

# HEPATITIS C:  Has never received Tx for same. 

# Hx ALCOHOL ABUSE and # Hx IVDU:  Patient denied recent use, no 
suggestion of intoxication, no withdrawal symptoms. 

# HYPOKALEMIA and # HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA:  In the setting of DKA and 
GI losses.  Repleted IV and PO.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted from the ED to the GYN service with the 
diagnosis of hematosalpynx thought to be related to 
anticoagulation from being on Xarelto. 
Please see below for detailed hospital course by system/problem:

1) Neuro: Ms. ___ had significant abdominal pain associated 
with a right hematosalpynx. She received IV pain medication 
however continued to have persistnet pain. APS was consulted who 
recommended a morphine PCA. This was continued until her diet 
was advanced to a regular diet after which she was transitioned 
to oral oxycodone and acetaminophen which controlled her pain 
adequately.

2) Hematosalypnx: This was thought to be related to beign 
anticoagulated on Xaralto. Therefore, this medication was held 
and all anticoagulation was held. The patient received multiple 
doses of Vitamin K and 2units FFP to reverse her coagulopathy 
following which her INR significantly improved. Although there 
was some suspicion for hemoperitoneum, her abdominal exam 
remained stable throughout with no hemodynamic instability or 
acute abdomen. She received 2 units pRBC for downtrending anemia 
with an appropriate response. 
The patient underwent an ___ guided drainage of right 
hematosalypnx with minimal fluid aspirated. There was no 
purulence noted at the time of drain. 

3) ID: the patient was noted to have a significant leukocytosis 
on admission. Due to some initial concern for pyosalpynx, the 
patient was started on gentamicin and clindamycin. She was 
afebrile until the day of above noted ___ drained when post 
procedurally she was triggered for a heart rate in the 130s and 
a temp of 101.4. She subsequently defevervesced with no further 
fevers. This was thought to be related to a inflammatory 
response after ___ drainage. Her antibiotics were subsequently 
discontinued given no clinical evidence of pyosalpynx or 
infection. ___ cultures did not grow anything.

4) GI: Initially, the patient had nausea, intermittent emesis 
and limited bowel function. She was maintained on a clear liquid 
diet due to concern for possible ileus and received a bowel 
regimen which significantly improved her symptoms. She was 
advanced to a regular diet without difficulty. Nutrtition was 
consulted given need for daily vitamin K who recommended Ensure 
supplementation. 

5) Heme: Patient was initially on Xaralto due to a history of 
superficial thrombosis and fam hx of DVT. Hematology was 
consulted who agreed with holding Xaralto on admission. Once 
hematocrits were stable with no evidence of ongoing bleeding 
into hematosalypnx, the patient was started on prophylactic 
anticoagulation (___ transitioned to lovenox, discharged on 
prophylactic lovenox). During her hospital stay, she had ___ 
ultrasound that was negative for a DVT (this was done to a 
complaint of lower extremity swelling)

6)Pulm: the patient had intermittent oxygen requirements. This 
was thought to be related to a combination of sleep apnea and 
fluid overload. A CTA chest was negative for a PE. A CXR showed 
possible fluid overload. Given clinical evidence of fluid 
overload (crackes on lung exam, ___ swelling) the patient 
received several doses of IV lasix and used the incentive 
spirometer following which she was weaned to room air without 
difficulty. The patient had normal ambulatory O2 sats prior to 
discharge.  

Ms. ___ was discharged home in stable condition on hospital day 
#8- ambulating independently, tolerating a regular diet and pain 
adequately controlled on oral pain regimen.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ man with CAD s/p CABG, CHF (EF ___, 
afib on coumadin and amiodarone, and s/p ICD placement (h/o 
inappropriate shocks for AF), who presented to the ED with acute 
onset SOB likely secondary to exacerbation of undiagnosed COPD 
prompting admission to ICU on ___ followed by transfer to 
Medicine floor on ___.

# Shortness of breath/hypoxemia
On arrival to the MICU, VS were 98 71 148/51 17 97% on Venturi 
mask. The patient was comfortable and reported his SOB had 
improved. Empiric antibiotics and nitro drip were discontinued 
given lack of evidence for PNA or fluid overload. Respiratory 
status continued to improve with steroids and nebs for presumed 
COPD exacerbation. TTE revealed no change in his severe heart 
failure with increased EF ___. CT chest revealed prior 
tuberculosis/granulomatous infection (no reactivation), 
moderately severe emphysema, and basilar ground glass opacities 
that could be pulmonary hemorrhage, drug reaction, or the early 
manifestation of chronic eosinophilic pneumonia. Because of the 
possibility of amiodarone-related pulmonary toxicity, home 
amiodarone was held. His respiratory status continued to improve 
on steroids and duo nebs and on transfer to the floor he 
reported almost his baseline respiratory status on nasal 
cannula. On the floor, he was continued on prednisone, 
azithromycin, and nebs, with decreased SOB, no tachypnea, and 
improving O2 sat. By the day of discharge, O2 sat was stably 
>90% on room air at rest and while ambulating. Patient was 
discharged on albuterol PRN and with early pulmonary follow up 
for new possible diagnosis of COPD and the question of 
amiodarone induced lung toxicity.
   
# Acute-on-chronic kidney disease
Baseline Cr 1.4-1.5. On admission, Cr was 2.3. This was though 
likely prerenal in etiology, although no obvious history of poor 
PO intake or GI losses. In the unit patient received NS @ 100 
cc/hr. Urine lytes demonstrated a FENA <1% and his Cr returned 
to its baseline level of 1.5 on ___. Home lisinopril and 
lasix were restarted on ___ and ___, respectively. Cr 
remained baseline 1.5 on day of discharge.

# Possible amiodarone toxicity
SOB and hypoxemia with GGOs on CT Chest could be secondary to 
amiodarone toxicity. LFTs were mildly elevated on ___, and 
normalized by ___. TSH was elevated at 11.0, T4 was normal. 
Cardiology/EP was consulted and recommended continuing to hold 
amiodarone, though stated that SOB was probably not due to 
amiodarone toxicity. Patient was scheduled for outpatient 
pulmonary follow up to further assess possibility of underlying 
amiodarone toxicity, as amio toxicity would warrant longer 
course of steroids. 

# CHF (EF ___ s/p ICD)
No evidence of acute volume overload on this admission (JVP 
~8cm, no leg swelling, CXR with cardiomegaly and e/o chronic 
volume overload). Repeat TTE this admission showed no 
significant change, increased EF ___. He was continued on his 
home digoxin and started on metoprolol (instead of his home 
atenolol, which is renally cleared, in the setting of ___. 
Additionally, his home lisinopril and lasix were held in the 
setting of ___. When ___ resolved, home lisinopril, lasix, and 
atenolol were restarted.

# Afib on coumadin
Patient with longstanding history of AFib s/p failed ablation 
and s/p ICD on coumadin. Started on amiodarone in ___ due to 
increasing fatigue, possibly due to AV dyssynchrony. Amiodarone 
held during admission and on discharge as above. He was in NSR 
throughout admission. EP interrogated the ICD, which 
demonstrated no inciting event to explain the sudden onset 
dyspnea. Patient declined ablation for rhythm control. His 
coumadin was held in the setting of a supratherapeutic INR after 
receiving vanc and cefepime in the ED (INR 4.2), which decreased 
to 2.2 by discharge. Patient was restarted on coumadin 2.5 mg QD 
with instructions for early follow up of his INR with his outpt 
cardiologist's office. Patient was scheduled for appointments 
with general cardiology and EP after discharge.

# Downtrending Hct
Patient's baseline Hct appears to be ___. Hct was 36 on 
admission ___ and decreased to 29.3 on ___, normocytic. 
Unclear etiology; the decreased Hct did not appear to be 
dilutional and there was no evidence of active bleeding. Hct was 
stable at 29.9 for the remainder of the admission.

# CAD s/p CABG
Admission EKG had no signs of active ischemia, and troponins 
were negative x2. He was continued on home ASA 81 mg and statin 
during admission.  

# Diabetes Mellitus, type II
Patient is on metformin at home, with good control (HgbA1c 6.2% 
on ___. Unclear if nephropathy is a complication of DM. 
During admission, he was placed on an insulin sliding scale and 
home metformin was held. Metformin restarted on discharge. 
 
# Hypertension  
Patient's home lisinopril was initially held for ___, and 
restarted after ___ resolved on ___. Home atenolol was 
replaced by metoprolol in the setting ___ (atenolol is 
renally cleared), and restarted after ___ resolved on ___.

# Hyperlipidemia  
Patient received home statin during admission.  

# Possible Aspiration in ICU
Due to concern for possible aspiration in the ICU, speech and 
swallow was consulted. They found no evidence of obvious 
aspiration, however the patient's O2 sat decreased from 91 to 
high ___ on RA while eating. Though the desats could have been 
due to silent aspirations, they were more likely due to the 
ongoing COPD flare, and video swallow was deferred. There was no 
other concern for aspiration for the duration of the admission.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___. You were admitted with shortness of breath, 
probably due to a flare of COPD (emphysema). You were initially 
in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU), and then you were transferred 
to a general medicine floor when your breathing improved. For 
your COPD flare, you were treated with prednisone (steroids), 
nebulizer treatments, azithromycin (antibiotic), and extra 
oxygen. Your breathing improved and by the time of discharge, 
you were breathing comfortably without extra oxygen, both at 
rest and when you were walking.

Because amiodarone may have contributed to your shortness of 
breath, it was stopped while you were in the hospital. You 
should NOT take amiodarone unless your cardiologist tells you to 
restart it. We also set up an appointment with you with a 
pulmonologist, who will assess if the amiodarone may have caused 
some lung damage. We gave you a copy of some test results from 
___ - please bring a copy of these to the 
appointment with the pulmonologist.

When you were admitted to the hospital, your INR was high, 
indicating that the coumadin had made your blood too thin. We 
stopped the coumadin until your INR was normal again. Your INR 
was 2.2 on ___. 

Because you are a reliable patient, you can restart your 
coumadin also known as warfarin at home. Take your coumadin 2.5 
mg per day at home, and call your anticoagulation service on 
___.

Please call your doctor or go to an Emergency Room if you 
develop worsening shortness of breath, fever/chills, worsening 
shortness of breath when walking, inability to lie flat, chest 
pain, dark stools, or blood in your stool. Also please weigh 
yourself every morning and call your primary care doctor if your 
weight goes up more than 3 lbs.

It was a pleasure taking care of you.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ F with DM, HTN, and HL presenting with chest 
pressure that has been on and off for the past 3 weeks, 
worsening with exertion yesterday. She had negative troponins. 
EKG showed increased LAD and questionable new LAFB. Stress MIBI 
was performed and showed no focal myocardial defects and an EF 
of 63%.

# Atypical Chest Pain, likely secondary to SVT- Patient has 
chest pressure and R arm pain, occasional nausea. Pain sometimes 
occurs with exertion, sometimes does not not. Given her risk 
factors (former smoker, hypertension, DMII, + family hx of early 
MI, central obesity) and history, there is concern for worsening 
angina. The patient is currently chest pressure free, troponins 
were negative, and EKG has some conduction disturbance, but no 
ST elevations > 1mm and is relatively unchanged from ___ EKG 
(although worsening LAD and questionable new LAFB). Patient is 
unfortunatley allergic to ASA (swelling of throat and dyspnea), 
so aspirin is deferred. Also allergic to IV dye. 
- Patient received a persantine stress MIBI as an inpatient for 
evaluation of angina with exertion
- Stress MIBI showed no focal myocardial perfusion defects and 
normal wall motion with an ejection fraction of 63%. The patient 
did have some atypical anginal symptoms with the injection of 
persantine 
- Patient recieved in patient echo prior to discharge due to new 
cardiac murmur. This showed no significant valvular abnormality, 
but did show mild LV outflow tract obstruction. She was 
hyperdynamic (EF 70%), which per attending cardiologist can 
exagerate this finding. Metoprolol was started for this reason 
as well, as rate control should reduce level of LVOT. 
- Throughout hospitalization continued outpatient meds for 
management of hypertension, with addition of lisinopril 5mg for 
improved blood pressure control in the setting of diabetes.
- Patient was also started on Metoprolol succinate 50mg for SVT 
and hypertension.
- TSH was WNL.
 
# PUMP: Pt w/ trace pedal edema which is baseline. Has 
increasing fatigue over the last three weeks.  
- Persantine stress suggested EF was 63%. 
 
# RHYTHM: Pt w/ what may be new anterior fascicular block on 
first EKG in ED, w/ existant RBBB. New EKG showed worsening LAD. 
 
 
# DMII: Slightly elevated ___ upon arrival (190s). Metformin was 
held during hospitalization and the patient was started on 
Insulin Sliding Scale. Her last HbA1C was 6.9 in ___. 
Patient was discharged on her home dose of Metformin.  
 
# HTN: Blood presures elevated during hospitalization (150s/80s 
- 170s/80s). Home blood pressure medications (clonidine and 
amlodipine) were continued. Lisinopril 5mg was added to the 
patient's hypertension regimen for improved control. Given 
benefit to patients with diabetes, ACE-I can be titrated up in 
the outpatient setting. Patient also started on Metoprolol 
Succinate 50mg daily.  

# Hypothyroidism: Stable. Patient was continued on 
levothyroximne. TSH WNL during this hospitalization.  
 
# Trigeminal Neuralgia: Stable during this hospitalization. 
Patient was continued on her home regimen.  

# Hyperlipidemia - Patient was continued on home Pravastatin 
20mg. 

# Elevated WBC count - Patient was admitted with a WBC count of 
13, down to 12 today. CXR and UA were not suggestive of 
infection. Patient has been afebrile during hospitalization, 
with no picture concerning for infection. 

Transitional Issues:
- Further consideration of potential causes of atypical chest 
pain.
- Optimize HTN medication regimen (titrate ACE-I and B-blocker).
- Control LVOT with metoprolol succinate, f/u with Cardiology

the gallbladder and the wall of the gallbladder is edematous.  
Gallbladder edema may be seen with hepatitis or heart failure, 
however in the setting of cholelithiasis with gallstone at the 
neck of the gallbladder, cannot exclude acute cholecystitis in 
the appropriate clinical setting. 

___ EXAMINATION:  Ultrasound procedure
Successful ultrasound-guided placement of ___ pigtail 
catheter into the gallbladder. Samples was sent for microbiology 
and chemistry evaluation. 5 cc of bilious secretions were 
aspirated after 10 cc of saline was instilled into the 
gallbladder.  Aspirated material was extremely thick and 
difficult to aspirate due to inspissation.

___ TTE
Endotracheal intubation performed days prior to study, and 
patient was sedated on propofol and monitored by nursing 
throughout the study. 

No spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus is seen in the body of 
the left atrium/left atrial appendage or the body of the right 
atrium/right atrial appendage. The left atrial appendage 
emptying velocity is depressed (<0.2m/s). No mass or thrombus is 
seen in the right atrium or right atrial appendage. The right

atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There are 
simple atheroma in the ascending aorta, aortic arch, and 
descending thoracic aorta. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are

leaflets consistent with Lambl's excresences (normal variant). 
Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral prosthesis 
appears well seated, with normal disc motion and transvalvular 
gradient. A very small paravalvular mitral prosthesis leak is 
probably present with mild (1+) mitral regurgitation. There is 
at least moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There 
is no pericardial effusion.

discs, normal gradients and mild paravalvular mitral 
regurgitation. Mild-moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Moderate 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

What did you receive in the hospital?
 - On imaging, you were found to have an gallstone leading to a 
gallbladder infection. You were given antibiotics. You 
eventually had a procedure that placed a tube into your 
gallbladder to relieve the pressure and clear out the infection. 
The tube in your gallbladder caused some bleeding in your 
abdomen so a procedure was performed to stop the bleeding.  
 - While we were monitoring you, your heart rate also slowed 
down significantly, a condition called complete heart block. You 
were given a temporary pacemaker to keep your heart rate up 
during the procedure. After you have your gall bladder removed, 
you will have a permanent placemaker placed. 

What should you do once you leave the hospital?
 - You will need to follow up with the surgeons who will arrange 
for removal of your your gallbladder surgically.  
 - You will need to follow-up with the cardiologists after your 
gallbladder is removed for a permanent pacemaker

#Ischemic to hemorrhagic conversion of PCA infarct, and R 
Caudate head infarct.

#ICU course
On admission to the neuro ICU, patient had MRI/MRA which showed 
PCA territory infarct as well as right head caudate infarct. MRA 
showed no vessel cutoffs. Bedside ultrasound of right IJ 
(incision at the site from OSH) showed large thrombus in right 
IJ. Cardiology was consulted regarding post-stent care, as well 
as medication recommendations. They recommended starting 
antiplatelet therapy as soon as possible, but were agreeable to 
holding for at least one week. In terms of what medication to 
start, they recommended a Plavix assay to confirm Plavix 
response, and if patient is a responder to begin with Plavix 
monotherapy, and monitor patient inpatient while the medication 
is started. They advised against continuing tamoxifen due to its 
coagulopathy side effect. In chart review, patient was found to 
have a large PFO. 

Patient experienced a flushing sensation ___ after 
administration of hydralazine, oxycodone, and Lidocaine. This 
was thought to be likely to Lidocaine, as he has an allergy to 
novacaine which also involved flushing. He experienced a similar 
flushing sensation ___ after metoprolol and acetaminophen. 
After the latter episode, the patient reported diffuse and 
moving paresthesias in his bilateral legs, back, arms, and face. 
These paresthesias did not follow a sensory distribution and 
were thought not to be a central process. On ___ platelet 
reactivity study was sent. Discussed incidentally found right IJ 
clot (seen on ultrasound ___, which could not be treated with 
anticoagulation in the ICU due to acute hemorrhage. Plan was 
made to plan for a follow up ultrasound in 3 months after 
discharge to ensure resolution. 

On the floor, Mr ___ improved quickly and had only a residual 
left homonymous hemianopsia at the time of discharge. 

Plavix was re-started on ___ and patient had repeat head CT on 
___ that was stable. If patient continue to do well, anticipate 
re-starting aspirin on ___.  Patient was otherwise started on 
atorvastatin 40mg daily. 

Stroke etiology has yet to be elucidated. Patient has known risk 
factors including a large PFO and tamoxifen is known to 
predispose patients to venous clot (though no venous clot 
identified apart from R IJ).  He also has sleep apnea as well as 
some calcification in the aortic arch seen on CTA.  Another

Discharge Instructions:
 Dear Mr. ___,

 You were hospitalized due to symptoms of changes in your vision 
resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE WITH HEMORRHAGIC 
CONVERSION, a condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen 
and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is 
the part of your body that controls and directs all the other 
parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived 
of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms.  

 Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:  
- recent heart surgery
- patent foramen ovale 

 We are changing your medications as follows:  
- STOP tamoxifen
- continue PLAVIX
- do not resume aspirin until ___

 Please take your other medications as prescribed.  

 Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.
  
 If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  
 - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
 - Sudden weakness of one side of the body  
 - Sudden drooping of one side of the face  
 - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body  

 Sincerely,  
 Your ___ Neurology Team

encephalopathies, but may be suggestive of diffuse cortical 
hyperexcitability 
with potential to evolve to seizures. 
  
2) Burst suppression pattern, slowing, and disorganization of 
the background, 
which is suggestive of a severe global encephalopathy that is 
nonspecific as 
etiology but causes can include medications/sedation, global 
hypoxic ischemic 
injuries. By the end of the recording, the background 
transitions to diffuse 
continuous slowing, which may be secondary to weaning of 
sedation but is 
suggestive of a severe encephalopathy.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history of DM, HLD, HTN, 
AAA s/p EVAR ___, ___, who presented with PAU at the 
top of the prior stent graft at level of renals.  He went to the 
OR on ___ for a PMEG.  Postoperatively, he did fine and was 
transferred to the VICU.  He had an episode of presumed 
aspiration and subsequent respiratory failure.  He was 
transferred to the ___ where he was treated for ARDS.  He 
remained intubated and sedated.  He was on intermittent 
pressors.  He was treated with CVVH. He was also treated with 
broad spectrum antibiotics for pneumonia. He went to the OR on 
___ for a trach and PEG.  

Neuro: Patient had difficulties with vent dysychrony and 
overbreathing on the ventilator, requiring multiple different 
sedation regimens, including midazolam, precedex, dilaudid, 
Haldol, propofol. He had no reliable neuro exam while on 
sedation. After he was stabilized on pressure support, he was 
weaned off of sedation and neuro exam improved to withdrawal to 
pain and some spontaneous movement of the face and left upper 
extremity. Psych was consulted for assistance in sedation 
management as patient had a significant history of anxiety. He 
also had several CT scans of the head due to poor mental status 
and ultimately an MRI, which showed an old infarct but nothing 
to explain his poor mental status. There was some questionable 
sign of meningitis on the MRI, which subsequently led to an LP 
being performed on ___, which was negative for bacterial 
and HSV infections. EEG showed moderate to severe encephalopathy 
and later on new generalized periodic discharged for which he 
was started on keppra on ___. Neurology service was 
consulted to help us manage these issues. 

During the week of ___, the patient's neuro exam was of 
spontaneous movement of all four extremities; he did not follow 
commands or track. Given agitation, he was started on Seroquel 
on ___. 

Cardiovascular: Patient had aflutter/afib requiring diltiazem 
drip and heparin drips. He was intermittently on prn metoprolol 
and was on pressors for most of his icu course, which was 
eventually weaned off. He underwent a TEE to rule out culture 
negative endocarditis, which was negative.

During the week of ___, the patient was transitioned from 
diltizem drip to po diltiazem. His po regimen was uptitrated due 
to continued Afib/flutter with rate in the 110's-130's. He had a 
brief 4 hour period where he converted to sinus rhythm on 
___, however, he went back into Afib/flutter with poor rate 
control. Hence, cardiology was reconsulted. During this week, a 
bridge from heparin gtt to Coumadin was started.  

Pulmonary: Patient experienced an aspiration event which led to 
development of ARDS and pneumonia. He subsequently reaspirated 
while in the ICU and intubated due to high tube feed residuals 
which worsened his ARDS. He received a trach/peg on ___ due 
to prolonged intubation. He required paralysis for a brief 
period due to respiratory acidosis and overbreathing on the 
ventilator while on pressure support. He was ultimately 
stabilized on pressure support. Pulmonary was consulted to help 
us with management of these issues, and predicted that he would 
have a prolonged period on the ventilator, likely several 
months. 

GI: After receiving his trach/peg, he was fed through TFs until 
he aspirated even with the Gtube to gravity on ___. TFs were 
then stopped and he was started on TPN. He was eventually 
restarted on ___ of TFs with no residuals, followed by 
an exchange to a GJ with ___ to allow for distal feeding on 
___. His tube feeds via the J-limb were increased to goal 
and were tolerated well without any aspiration events. 

Renal: Patient developed ATN and CRRT was initiated to help with 
fluid removal to optimize his pulmonary status. He was trialed 
off of CRRT twice, which was not well tolerated. He eventually 
started making more urine even while on CRRT. Renal was 
consulted to help with management.

A tunneled dialysis catheter was placed on ___ in planning 
for intermittent HD.

aspiration pneumonia. He was on vanc/zosyn from ___ and 
linezolid/zosyn (___). He was briefly on micafungin, which 
was discontinued after cultures were negative and the BDglucan 
was felt to be a contaminate. Other than pneumonia, no other 
sources of infection were ultimately identified. ID consult was 
obtained to assist us with these issues.

of mitral regurgitation may be significantly UNDERestimated.] 
There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There 
is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Rheumatic valvular disease with moderate mitral 
stenosis and moderate aortic regurgitation. Mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with preserved global and regional 
biventricular systolic function. Moderate pulmonary 
hypertension.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo f with hx of HTN, HL, and DM presents to OSH with 
worsening dyspnea on exertion and acute chest pain. She ruled in 
for NSTEMI was transferred to ___ for cardiac catheterization. 

.  
#. CAD: No known diagnosis of CAD on arrival to OSH. Pt has 
multiple risk factors for coronary disease including HTN, HL, DM 
and history of tobacco abuse. Her presentation with SOB, 
atypical chest pain, nausea and diaphoresis were concerning for 
ACS.  Reports from OSH indicate positive cardiac enzymes with a 
troponin of 0.4 (per verbal signout). Stress test also reportly 
had anterior and anterior-apical changes. Cardiac cath performed 
on arrival to ___ showed no significant coronary artery 
disease.  Catheterizations did, however, show evidence of 
elevated pressures throughout the heart.  This likely indicates 
that it was not coronary occlusion that caused the elevated 
troponin rather heart failure.  Plavix and heparin were 
discontinued after cath and pt was continued on aspirin, 
betablocker, ACEI, and statin.
.  
#. Pump: No known history of heart failure.  However, clinical 
presentation, history, and cardiac cath results support 
diagnosis of diastolic heart failure. Pt reports elevated blood 
pressure at time of dyspneic episode that would support pump 
failure. Etiology of heart failure was undetermined at time of 
admission.  Pt had known potential for significant valvular 
disease given known MVP, history of Rheumatic fever, and MR 
identified on cath. Cardiac cath performed on admission showed 
markedly elevated pressures throughout the heart. Echo was 
performed the follow morning showing diastolic dysfuction as a 
result of mitral stenosis (see results).  Pt was placed on fluid 
restriction, low salt diet and started on a lasix gtt.  Symptoms 
greatly improved overnight with diuresis.  Pt was also managed 
with heart rate control to reduce pulmonary hypertension.  
Because pt responded so well to diuresis and rate control there 
is no indication for surgical intervention at this time. Pt will 
continue to be medically managed with metoprolol tartrate 150mg 
bid for rate control (goal heart rate 60) and lasix 40mg po bid 
for afterload reduction. Pt was counseling on maintaining a low 
sodium diet, fluid restriction and weighing herself daily.  Pt 
is to follow up with her primary care provider to have her blood 
pressure, heart rate, and electrolytes monitored on her new 
regimen.  She is also instructed to have biannual 
echocardiograms to evaluate the status of her mitral stenosis.
.  
#. Diabetes: poorly controlled; Home oral hypoglycemics where 
held in setting of catheterization; Pt was monitored with fsbs 
qachs and treated with lantus 25 u qpm and sliding scale humolog 
at meal time. Pt's blood sugars remained elevated throughout 
hospitalization (range from 200-400).  Pt instructed to resume 
home hypoglycemic regimen and diabetic diet at home with 
frequent glucose monitoring.  Pt is to follow up with primary 
care doctor to discuss augmenting her regimen if elevated sugars 
persist at home.
.  
#. Hyperlipidemia: continue home meds of lipitor and tricor
.

Discharge Instructions:
You were transferred to this hospital to undergo a cardiac 
catheterization.  The catheterization did not show any blockages 
in the blood vessels that supply the heart.  However, it did 
show that you have high blood pressures within your heart.  To 
determine why you have these elevated pressures you had an 
echocardiogram performed.  This showed a tight valve within your 
heart.  This is most likely the cause of your symptoms.  You 
were treated with medications to reduce the pressures within 
your heart and to make your breathing easier. You tolerated the 
medications well and it was determined that you are not in acute 
need for any surgical intervention at this time. You will need 
to continue some of these new medications after you leave the 
hospital.
.
During your hospitalization you developed a bladder infection in 
the setting of a bladder catheter.  The catheter was removed and 
you were started on a three day course of antibiotics.  You 
should complete this course at home and follow up with your 
primary care provider.
.
While inpatient your glucose was significantly elevated.  You 
were treated with insulin while inpatient.  You are advised to 
return to your home oral hypoglycemic regimen after you leave 
the hospital and to follow up with your primary care physician 
within one week to discuss changing your current regimen.  
Please check your glucose regularly and alert your primary care 
physician if you have a glucose above 400.
.
The following changes were made to your medications:
1) INCREASE Metoprolol Tartrate to 150 mg by mouth daily
2) START furosemide (lasix) 40mg by mouth twice a day.
3) START bactrim-DS 1 tablet twice a day for four doses (last 
dose on ___ morning)
4) STOP Premarin.  Please discuss the need for this medication 
with your primary care physician before restarting.
.
Please continue all other medications as previously directed.
.
Please notify your physician or return to the hospital if you 
experience worsening shortness of breath, chest pain, 
palpitations, loss of consciousness, fever, chills, or any other 
symptom that is concerning to you.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ w/ complicated PMH significant for DM2, ESRD on HD, gout, 
sleep apnea, asthma on 3L home O2, afib not on warfarin, chronic 
L achilles wound and L breast wound, sent from primary care for 
lethargy and fever.

# Lethargy: Patient had reported lethargy in clinic. In ED and 
on floor, patient had been completely awake and fully oriented. 
This was most likely from the E.coli that grew from her breast 
wound.  This was managed initially with vancomycin, 
ciprofloxacin and flagyl.  But once the cultures came back 
positive, vancomycin was discontinued as she only required 
gram-negative coverage. Her blood cultures are still pending. 
She had associated abdominal tenderness and CT imaging results 
were indicative of a small area of bowel ischemia. Given her 
A-fib without anticoagulation, it is possible she may have 
thrown a clot to her intestinal vasculature.  This was managed 
with 24 hours of bowel rest and resolved. An ECHO ruled out a 
myocardial thrombus. In-house her gabapentin was also 
discontinued due to its effects of lethargy.

 # intermittent bradycardia: Pt had reported episodes of 
bradycardia when she "feel asleep" in urgent care clinic, w/ HR 
down to ___, but then back up to ___ when awoken. Unclear 
what her O2 sat or RR was during these periods, but it is 
possible that her lethargy, possibly from opiate medications 
described above, led to worsening of her known obstructive 
apnea, and transient hypoxia, which may reduce heart rate. She 
refuses CPAP. In-house, her opiate dosing was decreased and 
gabapentin was discontinued.  Her heart rate was stable in the 
___. 

# atrial fibrillation: not on anticoagulation. Per daughter and 
PCP, this was due to concern that warfarin was making her breast 
and L achilles wounds worse, but her CHADS2 score is 4, which is 
high risk, though stroke was thalamic so possibly due to bleed.  
PCP to ___ with out-patient cardiologist and nephrologist to 
assess patient's current requirement for warfarin. PCP did reply 
in email explaining that he had a risk benefit conversation 
(especially given bleeding risk from calciphylaxis) about 
warfarin and that the patient and her family chose against 
warfarin after making an informed decision. 

# L achilles wound: Pt was just seen by podiatry ___, who 
felt wound had moderate amount of purulent type drainage with a 
slight odor, with fibrotic base of wound but no purulence and 
moderate exudate.  In-house managed with Aquacel Ag dressings.  
Patient has out-patient podiatry follow up.

#Left breast wound.  Chronic over a few months.  Being dressed 
by nurse at home. Slight odor. Fleshy erythema surrounding a 
crusted center. Biopsied prior to admission which was indicative 
of wound likely secondary to calcifilaixis from renal failure. 
Wound cultures also grow E.coli.  She was managed as above with 
ciprofloxacin and flagyl

ACUTE ISSUES:
================
# Crohn's disease
# Chronic diarrhea and weight loss
# Perirectal abscess and fistula
He presented with a compelling story of weight loss and chronic 
diarrhea. Has had large workup, which has thus far been notable 
for positive Celiac markers HLA-DQ2/DQ8 without pathologic 
diagnosis of Celiac disease (including normal tTG-IgA) although 
he has been adherent to a gluten free diet. He has been told he 
has Celiac disease in the past. Push enteroscopy revealing for 
discontinguous and strictured jejunum which, in the setting of 
perirectal abscesses was consistent with Crohn's disease. Final 
path from push enteroscopy showed non-necrotizing granulomas and 
chronic enteritis. Old pathology report also suggestive of 
Crohns without intraepithelial leukocytes. He likely has had 
Crohns disease all along. Per gastroenterology, he was taken off 
gluten free diet and tolerated a regular diet in house without 
any issues. He was started on prednisone 40mg daily which he is 
to remain on until his follow up outpatient appointment with 
gastroenterology Dr. ___.

Regarding perirectal fistula, this was evaluated by our 
colorectal surgery team and with an MRI pelvis.  There is no 
drainable pocket for now.  He should be scheduled for outpatient 
colorectal surgery follow up in ___.  Recommend Dr. ___ 
___ this.

# Anorexia
# Severe Malnutrition
# Protein Losing Enteropathy 
# Hypoalbuminemia
Unintentional weight loss of ~60 lbs since ___ in the 
setting of poor PO intake and intermittent diarrhea. Low albumin 
of 1.9 consistent with severe malnutrition. Nutrition was 
consulted. Electrolytes were checked frequently and patient was 
monitored on telemetry for re-feeding syndrome and 
electrolyte-related arrhythmias. He temporarily required TPN to 
boost his nutrition and then was discontinued shortly 
thereafter. He tolerated a regular diet and was given vitamin 
supplementation daily.  He does NOT require a gluten-free diet.

# Cholecystostomy tube
Placed at ___ in ___ for conservative 
management of suspected cholecystitis (positive ___ sign, 
gallbladder distention of RUQUS, though no CBD dilation or 
pericholecystic fluid). Patient is a poor candidate for surgery 
given his overall deconditioning and poor nutritional status. 
Surgery was consulted and they recommended T tube cholangiogram 
which showed patent biliary tree and patent cystic duct. Surgery 
removed the percutaneous cholecystostomy tube without any 
further issues.

# Neutrophilic leukocytosis
Patient remained afebrile, HD stable, and normoxemic in room air 
without any localizing symptoms. Infectious workup negative. 
Likely leukemoid reaction vs demarginalization in setting of 
starting steroids.  WBC count on day prior to discharge 18.7.

# ___
Baseline Cr of 0.9 in ___, up to 1.4 on admission. 
Suspected to be pre-renal azotemia in the setting of poor PO 
intake and diarrhea. Resolved with TPN and fluids. Renal was 
consulted for additional assistance and they also recommended 
IVF.  Cr day prior to discharge is 1.3, likely his new baseline.

#LLE swelling: has had this for many years. Likely ___ 
hypoalbuminea and venous insufficiency. Low suspicion for 
cardiac etiology given unilaterality. Bilateral LENIs were 
negative for DVT. He was recommended to elevate the leg and wear 
compression stockings. His swelling improved with resolution of 
home Lasix and aldactone.

#Anemia: 
Normocytic, likely related to anemia of chronic disease, not 
iron deficient. No evidence of hemolysis.

# Atrial fibrillation
INR of 2.7 on admission. Decision made to stop anticoagulation 
with warfarin given CHADS2VASC of 1 (1 point for age). He was 
started on aspirin during this admission. He had intermittent 
tachycardia with movement thought to be the result of 
deconditioning rather than poorly controlled afib. He was rate 
controlled on metoprolol succinate 50mg daily and digoxin (dose 
reduced to 0.625 in setting of renal function).

#Hyperglycemia: developed in setting of steroids. Was controlled 
with minimal ISS.

#Melena: Developed following push enteroscopy procedure. 
Stabilized without intervention. He had no further episodes of 
melena thereafter.

#Transudative left pleural effusion: etiology appears to be 
consistent with hypoalbuminemic state. No clinical signs of 
heart failure. His nutritional status was optimized as above. He 
underwent a thoracentesis with IP to have 1L of fluid removed. 
Repeat CT showed reinflation of the lung with resolution of the 
pleural effusion. He will need continued follow up given 
likelihood of reaccumation.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old gentleman admitted to the Acute Care service s/p 
gunshot wound to his abdomen.  Initially admitted to an OSH, 
where he was intubated,  required intravenous fluids and blood 
products.  
 
Upon admission, he was found to have a hemo-peritoneum.  He was 
urgently taken to the operating room where he underwent an 
exploratory laparotomy and small bowel resection.  During his 
operative course, he required additional blood products.  He had 
an 1800cc blood loss.  He was monitored in the intensive care 
unit after his surgery where he required pressors for blood 
pressure support. Once his blood pressure stabilized, his 
pressors were weaned.   He was extubated on POD #1 and was 
maintained on antibiotics for 48 hours.
Social work services were consulted once he was extubated.

He was transferred to the regular floor on POD #2.  His 
post-operative pain was managed with Dilaudid PCA. He did have 
an isolated episode of decreased oxygen saturation related to 
his abdominal discomfort and his pain regimen was readjusted. He 
did experience abdominal distention with slow return of bowel 
function and received methylnaltrexone with passage of flatus.  
His PCA was discontinued once clear liquids were tolerated and 
his diet was gradually advanced.  He had adequate pain relief 
with oral Dilaudid and Tylenol.

He ambulated with some difficulty initially and required walking 
with a walker. Currently he is walking independently on his own 
but will be sent home with a walker if he needs it. His surgical 
wound is healing well.  His vital signs are stable and he is 
afebrile.  After an uncomplicated recovery he was discharged to 
his mothers home on ___ and will follow up in the Acute Care 
Clinic in 2 weeks.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with a gunshot wound to the 
abdomen. You also had injury to your left flank.  You were taken 
to the operating room for a resection of your bowel.  You are 
now preparing for discharge home with the following 
instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.

*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.

*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.

*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.

*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:

*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.

*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.

*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.

*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.

*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery
