___-SPINE: There is visualization of the skull base through T1. 
There is no evidence of acute fracture. However, anterior 
splaying of the intervertebral disc space at the C6-7 level is 
concerning for ligamentous injury. There is no 
spondylolisthesis. There is no paravertebral hematoma seen. 
  
Multilevel degenerative changes are seen. There is mild 
narrowing of the spinal canal due to posterior osteophytes at 
the C5-6 level and also due to disc osteophyte complex at the 
C7-T1 level. Uncovertebral hypertrophy and facet hypertrophy 
cause severe narrowing of the right neural foramen at the C4-5 
level. Uncovertebral hypertrophy causes moderate bilateral 
neural foramen narrowing at the C5-6 level. Uncovertebral and 
facet joint hypertrophy cause severe neural foraminal narrowing 
at the C6-7 level. 

CT HEAD: No evidence of intracranial hemorrhage. Hypodensity in 
subcortical and periventricular white matter in right 
occipital/parietal region may represent chronic small vessel 
ischemia. MR may be performed for more sensitive evaluation of 
acute infarct if of clinical concern. 
  
CTA head/neck: Bilateral partially calcified plaques at carotid 
bifurcations, with at least 50% stenosis on the right. Left 
vertebral artery dominant, with intermittent flow seen in 
diminuitive right vertebral. Intracranial arteries patent; small 
basilar with patent PComs bilaterally. 3D reformats pending. 
Scattered rounded pulmonary opacities and atelectasis. Anterior 
splaying of C5-6. ETT/NGT. Ethmoid mucosal thickening & fluid in 
nasopharynx. 

CT Torso:
1. Multifocal pulmonary opacities concerning for multifocal 
pneumonia, although there is also likely a component of 
aspiration. Atelectasis involving right upper and bilateral 
lower lobes. ETT slightly low. 
2. No evidence of acute intra-abdominal pathology. Colonic 
diverticula, without evidence of diverticulitis. 

___ Radiologic Studies
MR/MRA brain:
1. A small subcentimeter focus of increased signal on the 
diffusion-weighted image, which may represent a small acute 
infarct versus T2 shine-through artifact. As this is not 
definitely identifiable on other sequences, a followup study, 
can be considered to assess stability of this finding and 
confirming its nature. 
  
2. Very small caliber of the distal vertebral and basilar 
arteries, which is grossly unchanged since ___. Prominent 
posterior communicating arteries, supplying the posterior 
circulation. This appearance may relate to atherosclerotic 
disease, as described previously.

MR ___ spine:
The axial GRE sequence is limited due to motion artifacts. 
However, confirming the findings of the recent CT of the 
cervical spine, there is widening of the disc space anteriorly 
at the level of C6-C7 with disruption of the anterior 
longitudinal ligament, anterior disc herniation with increased 
signal within the disc, which can relate to edema. In addition, 
there is also evidence of injury to the anterior longitudinal 
ligament at the level of C5-6 with widening of the disc space 
anteriorly with increased signal of the disc, representing 
edema. There is also diffuse disc bulge with posterior central 
disc extrusion with superior migration. Theposterior 
longitudinal ligament is displaced anteriorly and has some 
increased signal within which can relate to edema or injury. 
There is effacement of the ventral thecal sac at this level, 
with moderate- severe compression on the cord. There is 
increased signal within the cord extending from the level of C4 
to C7 from cord edema versus contusion. This linear focus of 
increased signal noted posterior to the C5 body (___) can 
represent small edpidural hematoma. 
  
At C2-3, small central focal disc protrusion is noted. 
  
At C3-4 moderate-sized central disc extrusion is noted causing 
mild indentation on the ventral thecal sac. 
  
At C4-5, there is posterior spondylotic ridge with uncovertebral 
osteophyte causing mild indentation on the ventral thecal side 
and bilateral neural foraminal narrowing. At C4-5, there is also 
increased signal in the disc, with anterior disc herniation and 
possible injury to the anterior longitudinal ligament at this 
level as well. 
  
At C7-T1, the disc space is grossly unremarkable but not 
adequately assessed due to artifacts on the axial sequences. 
  
There is moderate amount of increased signal in the prevertebral 
soft tissues, representing edema versus hemorrhagic contusion. 
  
On the STIR sequence, there is also increased signal in the 
interspinous and the posterior spinous soft tissue at the level 
of C5 and C6, representing possible edema or injury to the 
interspinous and supraspinous ligaments (series 5, image 10). 
Patient is intubated, with increased signal from fluid in the 
sphenoid and the maxillary sinuses. 
  
In the left lobe of the thyroid, there are areas of increased 
signal intensity seen on the sagittal T2 (series 5, image 10; 
series 6, image 27), which represent cysts or adenoma, not 
adequately assessed.

History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ right-handed male with a past 
medical history significant for hypertension, panhypopituitarism 
since a benign pituitary adenoma in ___, panic and anxiety, and 
BPH, who presents with an episode of left hand 
weakness/clumsiness this morning followed by an episode of left 
leg weakness this afternoon.
 
The patient was in his usual state of health this morning when 
he was trying to put an earring in his wife's ear.  While he was 
doing this, he noticed a sudden onset of a strange feeling in 
his left hand.  He is a little unclear about what this feeling 
was.  He believes there was perhaps some tingling or the 
sensation that the hand was asleep.  He also felt that he might 
be having some difficulty with coordination trying to get the 
earring in his wife's ear.  He is unsure if there was any actual 
weakness.  He stopped doing what he was doing and proceeded to 
shake the hand for a brief period of time.  He believes the 
sensation lasted for about a minute and then resolved.  After 
the episode had ceased, he was able to then put the earring in 
his wife's ear, a task which apparently requires some degree of 
dexterity. 
 
After that episode, he did not think anything of it and he 
continued to go about his day.  According to both he and his 
wife, the rest of the day was uneventful until the early 
afternoon when he went to fill a prescription at his pharmacy.  
The patient was driving in his car and he noticed when he was 
attempting to get out of the car, his left leg was both stiff 
and weak.  The patient has had a number of problems with left 
leg stiffness in the past; however, this was unlike other 
episodes.  He felt his left leg was dragging and he was unable 
to put any weight on it.  He was barely able to take a few steps 
before he felt he was going to give out and fall down.  However, 
someone in the pharmacy caught him and laid him down on the 
floor.  The patient felt that he would have fallen due to the 
lack of power in the left leg.  There was no pain with this 
episode.  The people in the pharmacy insisted that he stay on 
the floor for approximately ___ minutes.  During that time, 
the patient did not test the leg, so he is not completely sure 
how long the episode lasted.  After the ___ minutes had 
passed, he insisted that he could get up and was able to do so.  
At this point, he believes he was walking normally, although he 
did feel that his left leg was somewhat stiff.  However, at this 
point, the stiffness was not significantly different than his 
usual left leg stiffness.  He spoke with his PCP who recommended 
that the patient come into the emergency room.  The patient was 
able to walk to his car, get in his car, and drove to the ___ 
Emergency Room.  He believes he is back at baseline, although 
feels his left leg is slightly stiff currently.
 
The patient has never had anything like this happen before.  He 
has never had any problems with carpal tunnel syndrome or 
tingling or numbness in his hands either left or right.  The 
patient has for many years, although he is not clear for how 
long, had difficulty with his left leg and left leg stiffness.  
However, he has never experienced significant weakness like this 
in the past.  He does report that sometimes he has some 
difficulty lifting up his leg and needs to lower his pants down 
to get his leg into it and sometimes when getting out of a car 
will aid leg in lifting it out of the car.  The patient 
otherwise has not had any headaches.  He has had no other focal 
numbness or weakness besides the above-mentioned problems.  He 
had no difficulties with speech.  He has never experienced any 
episode like this before.  He has never had episodes of focal 
weakness in the past before either.
 

On neuro ROS, the pt denies headache, loss of vision, blurred 
vision, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, lightheadedness, 
vertigo, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies difficulties 
producing or comprehending speech.   No bowel or bladder 
incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait.
  
On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or

palpitations.  Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation 
or abdominal pain.  No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. 
 No dysuria.  Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash.

Brief Hospital Course:
Cervical Spondylosis/Canal Stenosis
Exam and history most consistent with this. Some confusion 
initially given left sided weakness in the context of a cavenoma 
in the right basis pontis, but cervical disease much more 
consistent with overall picture. Exam actually worsened after 
admission with increased leg stiffness/tone, left patella 
clonus, bilateral upgoing toes. Has not previously had neck 
pain. Exam worse than MRI, but flexion extension imaging not 
performed owing to worsening and concern for exacerbation. MRI 
c- and t- spine was performed, along with CT c-spine. 
Neurosurgery was consulted and recommended Medrol steroid dose 
taper, rigid collar and muscle relaxants. Thus, hydrocortisone 
10 mg BID was held while Medrol started and will need to be 
restarted wihen Medrol completed. This resulted in hypertension 
which will need to be followed closely as below. Typical 5 mg 
diazepam daily was rescheduled as 2 mg q8h. His exam improved 
somewhat in rigid collar and with Medrol, but we felt that he 
was not sufficiently independent to return home. Thus, he is 
discharged to rehabilitation. We expect that further clinical 
improvement will be seen. He should be seen by Neurosurgery in 
clinic in two weeks. He should remain in an Aspen rigid collar 
until that time. 
 
Hypertension
Amlodipine was increased to 10 mg QD from 5 mg, enalapril to 20 
mg BID from QD and atenolol was changed to carvedilol given 
blood pressures around 200 systolic. This began prior to steroid 
treatment, but uptitration of these medications in part occurred 
during steroid treatment. It will be essential to follow his 
blood pressure closely and down-titrate medications if there is 
a fall in his blood pressure with steroid taper. 
  
Hypopituitarism
After adenoma and radiation in ___. Radiation is the likely 
cause of cavernomas, of which he has several (see MRI report). 
Testosterone and levothyroxine were continued. Hydrocortisone 
was held in the context of methylprednisolone treatment, but 
will need to be restarted immediately on completion of last dose 
Medrol, lest he become Addisonian. This is very important. 
 
BPH
Continued to exhibit urgency and small volume urination, with 
some worsening due to spinal disease. Condom catheter was used 
for much of the admission. Finasteride was continued.
  
Glaucoma
Ophthalmic medicatons were continued. 
  
Depression/Anxiety
Buspirone and celexa, along with diazepam were continued. He was 
quite anxious about his new gait difficulties, but this was 
appropriate and understandable. Thus, these longer-standing 
problems were not really active issues during the admission. 
 
Leukocytosis
Attributable to steroid dosing. No bands.

Brief Hospital Course:
=================
SUMMARY STATEMENT
=================
Ms. ___ is a ___ with a limited past cardiac history who 
presented with NSTEMI found to have clean coronary arteries on 
LHC and a dilated, hypokinetic RV on TTE. Ms. ___ presented 
with typical anginal symptoms with mild troponin elevation and 
no ischemic EKG changes. She had a coronary angiography that did 
not show significant disease and an ECG that demonstrated RV 
dilation with depressed free wall contractility with a normal PA 
systolic pressure. She did not have any other anginal symptoms 
after presentation. The differential for her RV hypokinesis 
includes thrombus (through no intracardiac shunt), microvascular 
disease, vasospasm or focal myocarditis. Given resolution of her 
symptoms and improvement of her cardiac enzymes, she was 
discharge home with plan for follow up TTE in several months. 

====================
ACUTE MEDICAL ISSUES
====================
# NSTEMI/Chest pain 
# RV Dysfunction
Ms. ___ presented with crushing substernal chest pain on two 
occasions in the 24 hours prior to presentation, occurring once 
while walking and once at rest. By presentation, she was chest 
pain free. However, she was found to have troponin-T elevation 
that peaked at 0.21 (her first lab drawn here) before 
downtrending. She did not have associated EKG changes 
(non-specific T wave inversions). LHC without CAD- making 
working diagnosis myocardial infarcation with non-obstructive 
coronary aterties (MINOCA), etiologies include myocarditis, 
thrombus, microvascular disease or vasospasm.

Etiology of isolated RV dilation and hypokinesis is unknown, 
though it is likely an incidental finding not related to her 
presentation. She did not have a intracardiac shunt that could 
help explain her findings. It is possible the etiology is 
secondary to a myocarditis, though it would be somewhat atypical 
to see isolated RV dysfunction. Vasospasm or transient thrombus 
are also on the differential. Primary pulmonary disease is less 
likely given her PASP was not elevated. She will be treated for 
primary prevention of CAD with ASA/statin. 

Of note, the patient experienced hypotension on two separate 
occasions shortly after oral Metoprolol. She should not be 
placed on beta blockade for that reasons. 
- ASA 81mg daily
- Atorvastatin 80mg daily
- D/c Metoprolol 12.5mg bid given hypotension with 
administration
- Repeat TTE in ___ to re-evaluate for RV dysfunction

units E. coil resistant to Bactrim and ampicillin/augmentin.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

It was a pleasure caring for you while you were admitted to ___ 
___. 

WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL?
- You were having chest pain and when you came to the hospital 
we found that you had evidence of damage to your heart, which 
made us worried you had blockages in the vessels of the heart. 

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL?
- We did a coronary angiography (catheterization) that did not 
show any significant blockages in your heart. 
- We did an ultrasound of the heart (echocardiogram) that showed 
some stretching of the right side of your heart. This does not 
require us to do anything now, but you will have another 
ultrasound in several months to ensure there are no changes. 

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO WHEN YOU GO HOME?
- Please carefully review the medication list that we provided 
to you, as we changed some of your medications. 
- Continue to be active and get regular exercise. 
- Call your doctor or go to an emergency room right away if you 
have chest pain again. 

Sincerely, 
___ Cardiology Team

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with diastolic CHF, atrial fibrillation who 
presented 3 days ago with R intertrochanteric fracture due to 
mechanical fall, now status post trochanteric-femoral nail whose 
post-op course was complicated by blood loss anemia, 
hypotension, and left subclavian arterial thrombus requiring 
thrombectomy. 

#Left subclavian arterial thrombus: Likely cardioembolic source 
given subtherapeutic INR. No history of arterial thrombi in 
past. Thrombocytopenia of new onset may suggest HITT, but she 
has clear other reasons and I feel that HITT would be much less 
likely than cardiac embolus. Additionally, platelets rebounded 
while on heparin. Transthoracic echo showed no ___. A 
hypercoaguable workup was not pursued as an inpatient, thinking 
that it would be low yield. She was restarted on home warfarin 
that she had been non-compliant with (admission INR 1.3), and 
bridged with heparin drip. 
   Of note, in the setting of her left arm arterial thrombus, 
stroke evaluation was undertaken before it was clear her arm was 
ischemic. She had no evidence of large vessel aneurysm or 
dissection on CTA of head/neck and, after her thrombectomy, an 
MRI of the head showed no acute infarct. 

#R hip fracture: Suffered from a mechanical fall at home landing 
on her right hip. She had trochanteric femoral nail placed on 
___. Post-op orders were for weight bearing as tolerated. 
Physical therapy saw the patient and recommended rehab for acute 
___. She has orthopedics follow up in ~2 weeks for repeat hip 
imaging. 

#Behavioral Changes: The family (3 children) were present for 
much of the admission. They expressed concern over their 
mother's perceived chronic to subacute personality changes. She 
had in the past months to ___ years become more forgetful and 
started not taking medications, such as warfarin, that she had 
been on for years. Their concern is that she still resides alone 
and is independent in ADLs, IADLs. However, she reportedly is 
not able to do tax papers reliably any longer, which is a change 
from previous years. The description of her slow decline sounds 
most consistent with incipient dementia. We had this 
conversation with the family and patient. Her neurologic exam 
was intact, though behaviorally she demonstrated inability to 
retain some basic facts of her hospital care. Neurocognitive 
evaluation was not undertaken.   
   Reversible causes were not investigated during this acute 
hospitalization, though she should have reversible causes of 
dementia ruled out as an outpatient. 

#Acute blood loss anemia: Hemoglobin was 11mg/dL on admission, 
but was near 15 last month. Much of this is likely acute blood 
loss from hip surgery in addition to left subclavian arterial 
thrombectomy. Her MCV is normal. She had a colonoscopy in ___ 
with polyps and diverticuli and EGD ___ that was normal. She 
would benefit from serial monitoring every month or so to 
demonstrate return to baseline. 

#Thrombocytopenia: Normal at 159 on admission, then dropped down 
to nadir of 108. Her platelets were 145 on day of discharge. 
Though HITT was considered and discussed extensively by Dr. ___ 
___ vascular surgery, and discussed again with Dr. ___ 
Dr. ___ likely represents consumption from blood loss and 
surgery, with HITT being quite unlikely given rebound of 
platelets while on continuous heparin infusion. Drop and timing 
of rebound is also typical of post-opereative recovery.  Have 
recommended that CBC be monitored at rehab for the next ___ 
days.

#Diastolic CHF: TTE showed findings similar to prior with normal 
LVEF, moderate PA systolic hypertension, and 1+ AR. She had been 
getting both Lasix 20mg daily and developed low blood pressure 
post-operatively, likely from some bleeding. Therefore, her 
Lasix was held. This should be given if she develops any signs 
of hypervolemia, worsened respiratory status, or elevated 
jugular veins. She appeared euvolemic at discharge.

#AFib with RVR: History of atrial fibrillation for years. She is 
on diltiazem for rate control and warfarin. Her CHADS2 score is 
2. She has been non-adherent per family for unclear reasons, 
though possibly related to early dementia. She was started 
emergently on heparin gtt for subclavian arterial thrombus. 
Heart rates were well controlled in 90-110s. Her diltiazem ER 
360mg dose was lowered for a few days because of borderline 
blood pressures (90s-100s). This should be titrated back up to 
her home dose of 360 mg.

CHRONIC/STABLE ISSUES:
#COPD: Home 2 liters O2. Chemistries showed elevated HCO3 
consistent with chronic CO2 retention. Continued home inhalers 
and O2.

#Left pleural effusion: Seen on imaging. Unclear etiology. Of 
note she has a history of RML lung nodules thought to be likely 
___ s/p radiofrequency ablation in ___. Subsequently she 
has had a history of bilateral effusions R>L. She has had 
extensive workup, including pleural biopsy in ___ ___s 
pleural cytology, both of which were negative for malignancy. 
Prior to that in ___ she had work up of pleural fluid that 
was negative for lymphoma/leukemia cells. Additionally, she had 
cytology in ___ that was likewise negative. 

#Pulmonary nodules: History of multiple CTs for past few years 
with multiple pulmonary nodules bilaterally. Last CTA chest in 
___ showed a stable 12 mm ground-glass nodule in right lower 
lobe since ___ and yearly followup was recommended. This 
admission, CTA neck showed a new 7 mm, not definitively 
identified on the previous Chest CTA. These should be evaluated 
with chest CT in ___ year.

#Hypothyroidism - Continued levothyroxine supplement.

Mr ___ is a ___ h/o ETOH cirrhosis c/b HRS s/p liver-kidney 
transplant ___, w/ subsequent chronic liver rejection s/p liver 
transplant ___ on MMF, tacro, and prednisone who was admitted 
for mild acute liver rejection on biopsy and transaminitis - 
thought to be due to missed doses of immunosuppressants. While 
hospitalized, he had a steroid burst with high dose IV 
Methylprednisolone. He was subsequently transitioned to PO 
Prednisone 20mg daily, and is to be slowly tapered in clinic. He 
tolerated the increased doses of steroids well. 

# ETOH cirrhosis c/b HRS s/p liver-kidney transplant ___, c/b 
chronic liver rejection
# S/P liver transplant ___:
# Mild acute transplant rejection:
Mild acute rejection on biopsy ___ with new elevations in LFTs. 
No obvious trigger other than medication non-compliance. Issue 
with timing of medications discussed at length with patient. 
Notable studies that were negative included: EBV mono spot, CMV 
VL, infectious work up including UCx (BCx pending at discharge). 
As such, he was given a steroid burst with IV Solumedrol 1g 
daily x3 day ___ and was transitioned to a higher dose 
of PO Prednisone 20mg qd afterwards. He is to take 20mg 
Prednisone from ___ - ___, and then 17.5mg Prednisone from ___ 
- ___, and then Prednisone 15mg from there after. He was also 
started on Valgancyclovir for CMV prophylaxis, as well as 
continued on Bactrim DS QOD for PCP/Toxo prophylaxis. He was 
continued on MMF 500mg BID and Tacrolimus (daily levels 
monitored and doses were adjusted accordingly). His Tacrolimus 
level at discharge was 4.2 and he was discharged on Tacrolimus 
5.5mg BID. His transaminitis initially improved with the steroid 
burst, and at discharge were AST 36 and ALT 79. 

# ESRD s/p liver-kidney transplant
Cr baseline most recently ~2.2-2.6 with evidence of stable but 
present DSAs. His creatinine was monitored daily, and ultimately 
his home Losartan was held during his hospitalization (as well 
as at discharge). 

#Chronic metabolic acidosis:
Secondary to ongoing diarrhea due to short gut syndrome and MMF. 
Continued home Bicarbonate 1950mg BID supplementation. 

#Short gut syndrome
Continue home Loperamide PRN. Held home Lomotil during his 
hospitalization, but this was restarted at discharge. 

#Hypertension 
Held home Losartan in the setting of ESRD, however continued his 
home Nifedipine.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You came to the hospital because you were having chest pain. The 
largest thing we worry about is a heart attack, particularly in 
you since you have had prior stents placed in your coronary 
arteries before. Thankfully, your EKGs did not show any evidence 
of a heart attack, nor did the markers for cardiac dysfunction 
in your blood, even after a repeated episode of chest pain you 
had overnight. Therefore, your symptoms are not from a heart 
attack. Unfortunately, we are unable to tell you what is causing 
them exactly; likely it is a component of your esophageal 
spasms, and therefore we have uptitrated your home nitrate. We 
have increased the dose of your isosorbide mononitrate from 120 
mg to 180 mg daily. Please follow-up with your outpatient 
gastroenterologist since he knows your esophageal spasm history 
the best, as well as your PCP to maintain overall good health. 

We wish you the best,
-Your ___ care team

Discharge Instructions:
What to expect when you go home:
1. Surgical Incision:
 It is normal to have some swelling and feel a firm ridge along 
the incision
 Your incision may be slightly red and raised, it may feel 
irritated from the staples

2. You may have a sore throat and/or mild hoarseness
 Try warm tea, throat lozenges or cool/cold beverages

3. You may have a mild headache, especially on the side of your 
surgery
 Try ibuprofen, acetaminophen, or your discharge pain 
medication
 If headache worsens, is associated with visual changes or 
lasts longer than 2 hours- call vascular
surgeons office

4. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day
 You may walk and you may go up and down stairs
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

5. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight
 Eat small frequent meals
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low
cholesterol) to maintain your strength and assist in wound 
healing
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
 No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
 No excessive head turning, lifting, pushing or pulling 
(greater than 5 lbs) until your post op visit
 You may shower (no direct spray on incision, let the soapy 
water run over incision, rinse and pat
dry)
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound,
then place a dry dressing over the area that is draining, as 
needed
 Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
 Take one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily, 
unless otherwise directed
 Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in 2 weeks for 
staple/suture removal

What to report to office:
 Changes in vision (loss of vision, blurring, double vision, 
half vision)
 Slurring of speech or difficulty finding correct words to use
 Severe headache or worsening headache not controlled by pain 
medication
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your arm or leg 
or the ability to feel your arm or leg
 Trouble swallowing, breathing, or talking
 Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ after 
a fall and were found to have a right scapular (shoulder blade) 
fracture and multiple right-sided rib fractures.  Your scapular 
fracture will heal on it's own and you have an appointment in 
the outpatient ___ clinic for repeat imaging.  Your rib 
fractures will heal on their own and it is important to use your 
incentive spirometer to prevent pneumonia.  

You have worked with Physical Therapy who recommend you be 
discharged to rehab to regain your strength. 

You are now ready to be discharged from the hospital.  Please 
note the following discharge instructions:

* Your injury caused right-sided rib fractures which can cause 
severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths 
because of the pain.
 
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.
 
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.
 
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.
 
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.
 
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.
 
* Do NOT smoke
 
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
 
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
Overnight on POD#0, the patient was unable to void and had to be 
straight cath'ed x1.  He was able to void thereafter.  On POD#2, 
the patient was complaining of calf tenderness.  He was sent to 
rule out a blood clot.  His LENIs were negative for blood clots. 
 Urines were also collected on POD#2 when his white count and 
temp were elevated.  His urinalysis was negative and urine 
culture was pending at time of discharge.  He will be contacted 
if the urine culture comes back positive.

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received Lovenox for DVT 
prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The surgical 
dressing was changed and the SIlverlon dressing was removed on 
POD#2. The surgical incision was found to be clean and intact 
without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen 
daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the 
hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign.

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity. Please use walker or 2 
crutches at all times for 6 weeks.

Mr. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.

6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.

7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).

8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your  Lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking Aspirin prior to your surgery, you should hold 
this medication while taking anticoagulation medication.   

9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by at follow-up 
appointment approximately two weeks after surgery. 

10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.

11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Two crutches or walker at all times for 6 weeks. 
Mobilize.  ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or heavy 
lifting until follow up appointment. 
Physical Therapy:
WBAT RLE
No range of motion restrictions
Assistive device x 6 weeks (i.e., 2 crutches, walker)
Mobilize frequently
Treatments Frequency:
daily dressing changes as needed for drainage
wound checks daily
ice
staple removal and replace with steri-strips (at follow up 
visit)

Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Minimally Invasive 
Microdiscectomy
 
Immediately after the operation:
 
-        Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 
lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit 
or stand more than ~45 minutes without moving around.
 
-        Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o   ___ times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes 
as part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate.
o   Limit any kind of lifting.
 
-        Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery.
 
-        Brace: You do not need a brace for your back.
 
-        Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the 
incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If 
it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once 
the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.  Call the office.
 
-        You should resume taking your normal home medications.
 
-        You have also been given Additional Medications to 
control your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___.  We are not allowed to call in narcotic prescriptions 
(oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to the pharmacy.  In addition, 
we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days 
from the date of surgery.
 
-        Follow up: 
o   Please Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks 
after the day of your operation if this has not been done 
already.
o   At the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take 
baseline X-rays and answer any questions. We may at that time 
start physical therapy.
o   We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the 
operation and at that time release you to full activity.
 
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound

Discharge Instructions:
.General Instructions

Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have 
been removed. If your wound closure uses dissolvable sutures, 
you must keep that area dry for 10 days. 
You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
 If you have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you 
will not require blood work monitoring.

Brief Hospital Course:
In summary, the patient is a ___ female with history of 
recurrent pulmonary emboli, lupus anticoagulant, asthma, common 
variable immunodeficiency and longstanding depression/PTSD, who 
was admitted after having a fall off of her desk chair with a 
resulting painful left buttock hematoma. This event occurred in 
the  setting of a recent supratherapeutic INR. After ED 
presentation, the patient also complained of some additional 
atypical chest pain of unclear etiology. Hospital course details 
outlined more fully below:
.
# Questionable Cellulitis/Abscess: Given her MRSA history and 
CVID, the ED staff was intially concerned with infection. 
However, she had no leukocytosis or fevers. ED staff consulted 
surgery service who opted to perform a left buttock I&D due to 
concerns that there may be an underlying abscess after there was 
a questionable collection noted on ultrasound. The 1 inch 
incision site drained blood but no observable pus or discharge. 
Later, after her transfer to the floor the patient was seen by 
the surgical service who re-dressed the wound and took a wound 
culture. Because she had no fevers or WBC elevations antibiotics 
were not continued. Initially it was felt that she just had a 
deep hematoma. She was discharged with ___ and daily wound care 
instructions. Blood cultures at time of discharge were negative 
to date. Wound culture final results were pending but wound gram 
stain showed no microorganisms, no leukocyes/PMNs. 
Unfortunately, the day after discharge she had cultures that 
grew out MSSA. PCP was contacted with update as the patient has 
a scheduled follow up planned for ___. The patient may need 
to be placed on an antibiotic regimen, particularly given her 
open wound and CVID history.  
.
#Left Buttock Hematoma: The patient had been placed on long term 
Warfarin therapy for recurrent PE history and known lupus 
anticoagulant. Of note, her most recent INR was supratherapeutic 
at 5.42 on ___. Around the same time, a week before her 
admission she explained that she fell out of her desk chair in 
her kitchen. She developed a large, expanding left buttock 
hematoma soon afterwards and had a brief admission to ___ 
___ and a few doses of her Warfarin were held. Upon 
admission to ___ she had an INR of 1.9 so the medicine team 
decided to continue her daily doses while she was an inpatient. 
She had a decline in her Hct from initial 27 down to 24 range 
after a lot of IVFs and bleeding in the setting of her I & D 
procedure. She also arrived to the medical floor with systolic 
blood pressures in the ___ range. She was asymptomatic despite 
fleeting hypotension. This was likely because of the multiple 
pain medications she had received in the ED. However, in the 
setting of a recent I& D and bleeding the team transfused her 
with 2 Units of blood. After this her Hct rose from 24 to 33 and 
then stabilized to about 30 by the time of discharge.  For pain 
management she was ultimately switched from all IV narcotics 
which were promoting bouts of hypotension to a lidocaine patch 
and then to PO Dilaudid by hospital day #2 which worked very 
well and achieved excellent pain relief according to the 
patient. Thus, she was continued on an additional 10 days of PO 
Dilauded upon discharge. She had her wound dressing changed BID 
and ice packs were given for additional comfort. ___ services 
were arranged for ongoing outpatient dressing changes, wound 
checks and INR lab draws.  
.
# Hypotension: The patient had some intermittent episodes of 
hypotension soon after transfer to the medical floor from the 
ED. There were some initial concerns for sepsis but in the 
absence of fevers, normal lactate levels and no leukocytosis 
this seemed unlikely. She was given Morphine, Fentanyl, 
Percocet, and Dilaudid within hours of each other. Thus, her low 
blood pressures were mainly a result of multiple pain 
medications. She responded very well to IVFs and her blood 
pressure medications and IV narcotics were all held until her BP 
stabilized. Fortunately, she remained asymptomatic and was in no 
distress despite SBPs in the mid to high ___ at times. She 
recovered gradually and by hospital day 2 she was normotensive. 
By hospital day 3 and 4 she was restarted back on her home 
Lasix. The rest of her blood pressure medications were restarted 
after discharge. 
.
# Atypical Chest Pain:  Per OMR noted the patient has been noted 
to have a chest pain syndrome of unclear etiology. She 
complained of chest pain that was at her lower sternum and 
radiating towards her back that oscillated between sharp pains 
and dull aches and lasted "hours" and sometimes days. A CTA was 
negative for PE/dissection and she was continued on Coumadin for 
her history of PE. She maintained healthy oxygen saturation 
levels between 93-97% on room air during her hospital stay. 
Three sets of cardiac enzymes returned negative, so ACS 
essentially ruled out. Follow up EKGs and telemetry were benign. 
CXR also unremarkable. She was written for  SL nitroglycerin but 
had no acute CP episodes after arrival to the floor. An exercise 
stress test was postponed given her negative cardiac workup to 
date and her inability to exercise without a lot of left buttock 
pain given her extensive hematoma. Thus, she was set up for an 
outpatient cardiac follow up with Dr. ___ at  ___ in 
___ who will review her complaints in more detail in the 
outpatient setting. She was continued on her usual Aspirin and 
her beta blocker was eventually restarted. 
.
# Anemia: Hematocrit baseline in low ___ and went to ___, then 
24. Gave patient 2 Units of blood on ___ and Hct rose to 33 
again, and was 30 at time of discharge. Blood loss was likely 
from the initial I&D of her hematoma site. Some of her Hct drop 
was related to pure dilutional effects with generous IVFs given 
in the setting of her low BPs after a plethora of pain 
medications.  Serial Hcts were monitored, and her wound site was 
assessed several times daily for any active bleeding. 
.
# Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID): Chronic condition. 
Splenomegaly noted on CTA. She has ongoing IVIG monthly 
infusions for managment. 
.
# Question of diastolic CHF : It is unclear whether patient 
actually has history of congestive heart failure per cardiology 
notes. However, she states that she has diastolic dysfunction. 
She was continued on her usual home lasix dosing after her blood 
pressures stabilized on hospital day ___. She will plan to 
follow up with her new cardiologist in a few weeks to explore 
additional testing and management. 
.
# Pulmonary Embolism history: Admission INR subtherapeutic at 
1.9. She was continued on her usual Coumadin therapy. Oxygen 
saturations were typically >95% on room air and she had no 
shortness of breath complaints. Moreover, CTA was negative for 
any pulmonary embolisms. Daily INR /___ levels were monitored and 
she was discharged with instructions for BID ___ checks 
through her home ___ services. 
.
#Depression: According to records the patient has a history of 
sexual abuse and PTSD as well as multiple psychiatric 
hospitalizations for despression and suicide attempts. She 
denied a history of borderline personality disorder and asked 
that it be eliminated from her PMH. This was addressed and she 
was advised to discuss this with her PCP as the medical team had 
limited background on this diagnosis. She had no signs of 
tearfulness or labile mood changes during this hospital stay. 
She also denied suicidal thoughts. She was continued on her 
usual doses of fluoxetine, klonopin, trazodone. 
.
#Obstructive Sleep Apnea: Despite this label per medical records 
she stated that she does not use any CPAP or BIPAP at home. 
Therefore she was monitored with oxygen saturation checks with 
vital signs but otherwise no additional interventions taken on 
this admission. 
.
#CTA breast finding : A small soft tissue nodular opacity was 
noted in the left breast measuring approximately 10 mm. Prior 
mammogram reports from ___ note a right sided region that had 
been biopsied and fibroadenoma identified but no left sided 
pathology noted. Thus, this new area of nodularity in left 
breast warrants follow-up with her PCP as outpatient (notified). 
No appreciable axillary lymphadenopathy on physical exam but 
full breast exam was not performed during this inpatient stay.  
.
# Fluids, Electrolytes and Nutrition: Electrolytes were 
monitored and repleted daily as needed, she was placed on a 
cardiac healthy diet PO, IVFs were also given for low blood 
pressures as needed for any fleeting hypotension with pain 
medications.
.
# Prophylaxis:
-She was continued on Warfarin anticoagulation therapy and 
PE/DVT prevention
-She was continued on her usual home PPI (Omeprazole BID)for now 
for her history of gastroesophageal reflux disease. 
-PO Dilaudid for pain control
-Senna/Colace were provided for a bowel regimen.
. 
#Code Status/Communication - Lastly, the patient was maintained 
as a full code status for the entirety of her hospital course 
and communication occurred on a daily basis directly with the 
patient.

Brief Hospital Course:
#Viral illness - Upon presentation, the patient had a fever with 
abdominal pain. She was initially started on Levaquin, and 
Falgyl was added out of nursing concern for aspiration. A RUQ 
ultrasound on admission did not show evidence of cholecystitis. 
During the hospitalization, she had a max temperature of 100.3. 
After this peak in temperature, the patient did not have any 
more temperature spikes. During the hospitalization, the patient 
noticed her symptoms of facial congestion improved. Her symptoms 
were thought to be due to a viral illness and antibiotics were 
discontinued. Blood and urine cultures and nasopharyngeal swab 
were collected and followed during the admission. Urine culture 
had no growth; blood cultures were still pending. Nasopharyngeal 
swab was negative. The patient was discharged home without 
antibiotics.   
.
#NSCLC stage IV EGFR wild type: Treating with palliative intent. 
The patient last received a cycle of chemotherapy ___ 
(Docetaxel) with Neulasta support on day 2. The patient's folic 
acid was discontinued during this hospitalization. She met with 
palliative care to discuss symptom management and goals of care. 
The patient expressed that she felt pretty clearly that she is 
not interested in more chemotherapy. During her discussion with 
palliative care, the patient acknowledged that her mood is low, 
but feels that she is just being honest with her situation. The 
patient's primary oncology team was made aware of the patient's 
decision and was fully on board with the patient's decision. She 
is being discharged home on hospice. During this 
hospitalization, the patient was started on Morphine SR 30mg 
every 12 hours for pain control. The patient was tolerating this 
medication well prior to discharge. 
.
#Metastatic brain lesions: Patient is status post whole brain 
radiation therapy. Ther was no indication for acute steroids 
during this admission.
.
#Leukocytosis - The patient leukocytosis was thought to be 
attributed to infection as with clinical improvement of the 
patient's symptoms, her white count was trended downward. 
.
#Nausea - Patient had Zofran available to her during the 
admission. Per palliative care recs, the patient was transition 
to three times daily dosing of Reglan with instructions to stop 
taking Compazine as the side effect profile of these two 
medications is similar. 
.
#Constipation - The patient was continued on scheduled senna and 
colace; she had lactulose available to her as needed for 
constipation. The patient did have a bowel movement prior to 
discharge. 
.
#Anemia - The patient did not require any blood transfusions 
during this admission.
.
#Hyponatremia - This has been a chronic issue for the patient 
with a likely component of SIADH given the patient's known 
history of brain metastasis.
.
#Transaminitis - Unclear etiology. Transaminitis was trended and 
the patient's AST was noted to be trending downward on day of 
discharge.  
.
#Adjustment disorder with depressed features secondary to 
general medical condition: The patient had ativan available as 
needed. No other medications were started for this during this 
hospitalization. 
.
#Transition of Care:
- Focus of the patient's care will now focus on comfort given 
her decision to be discharged home to home hospice. 
- Follow-up of pending blood cultures.

Pertinent Results:
Cath report: ___
Coronary Anatomy
Dominance: Right
LMCA: The LMCA was long with mild ostial plaquing.
LAD: The mildly calcified proximal LAD tapered gradually to an 
80% stenosis with TIMI 2 pulsatile flow
beyond. The mid-distal LAD was very straight, but did not appear 
on a pseudo-lateral view to be intramyocardial. D1 had mild 
proximal disease. D2 was another large branch. LCX: The CX gave 
off a patent very high OM1 (functionally a ramus intermedius 
branch). The proximal
and mid AV groove CX had mild plaquing to 20%. The terminal 
segments of all the OMs were tortuous, suggestive of 
hypertensive heart disease. OM2 was small and OM3 was of modest 
caliber. OM4/LPL had a hairpin turn prior to its terminal 
tortuosity. The distal CX provided collaterals to a bifurcation 
that was likely the distal AV groove RCA and a RPL2. Flow in the 
OMs was pulsatile, consistent with microvascular dysfunction.
RCA: The RCA gave off a very early RV branch arising from a 
slightly angulated segment. The RPDA appeared to be stump 
occluded with filling of the apical segment via the high early 
RV branch. RPL1 appeared to be a branching vessel with its first 
two bifurcating sidebranches running laterally and the main pole 
running parallel to the absent RPDA. The distal AV groove RCA 
beyond this RPL appeared to be occluded, filling via 
left-to-right collaterals.
Intra-procedural Complications: None
Impressions:
1. Severe proximal LAD and likely totally occluded distal RCA 
disease (terminal AV groove RCA and
RPDA proper) in a young woman with poorly controlled diabetes 
mellitus.
2. Normal left ventricular diastolic pressures.

regional/global systolic function (biplane LVEF = 68 %). The

aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve 
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. 
There is no mitral valve prolapse. The estimated pulmonary 
artery systolic pressure is normal. There is a 
trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.

preserved regional and global biventricular systolic function.

MICU Course: ___
Patient was admitted to the MICU for hypotension that required 
pressers. He was placed on broad spectrum antibiotics 
(Vancomycin, Cefepime, and Azithromycin). He was a taken off 
pressers immediately after coming to the MICU and was stable. 
After taking his medications in the morning he did drop his 
blood pressures and was ultimately needed fluid bolus and the 
restarting of pressers. Pressors were again switched off and he 
remained stable. He was called out and discharged to the floor 
on ___. At this time we believe his hypotensive episodes are 
more likely autonomic/neurologic or medication related or 
cardiac and unlikely related to infection.

Upon transfer to the medical floor on ___, chronic pain service 
reviewed patient's home regimen, and suggested patient resume 
his home pain medications. Patient was monitored on this 
regimen, and remained stable hemodynamically.

# Hypotension: 
Intermittent hypotension most likely related to medication side 
effect vs. autonomic dysfunction in the setting of HIV 
infection. No infectious symptoms, though treated for UTI given 
E. coli becteruria. Patient completed a 3 day course of 
ceftriaxone for UTI. Patient was initially treated for possible 
CAP with ctx/azithro, though no evidence of infiltrate on CXR, 
and CAP course was abbreviated. Endocrine workup negative for 
adrenal insufficiency. Patient is on multiple medications that 
can contribute to somnolence, including opioids, 
benzodiazepines, and tizanidine, but none should cause 
hypotension. Autonomic neuropathy is common in HIV, and occurs 
more commonly with increasing burden of disease. Patient was 
arranged with neurology follow-up to address possible autonomic 
dysfunction.

# Chronic pain/opioid use:
Upon admission, many of home pain medications were held out of 
concern for contribution to hypotension. He was treated with 
oxycodone while holding home medications, which did not provide 
adequate analgesia. Spoke with chronic pain, who noted that home 
opioids, tizanidine, and lyrica can all be sedating, though 
unlikely to cause hypotension. Patient was resumed on home 
regimen without new prescriptions. Upon review of records, PCP 
was reluctant to continue to prescribe opioids going forward, 
given concurrent alcohol use. Patient was encouraged to abstain 
from alcohol, and expressed understanding. He has follow-up 
arranged with PCP as well as chronic pain clinic next week. 

# Alcohol use: 
Last drink AM ___. No history of withdrawal seizures. Patient 
was monitored on CIWA scale, and was continue on home clonazepam 
for anxiety.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ 
because you were having periods of very low blood pressure. We 
looked into many possible causes of your low blood pressure. One 
thing that may have contributed to your low blood pressure was 
an infection in your urine. We started you on treatment for this 
urinary infection. We also reviewed your pain medications, and 
ultimately resumed your home doses, but encourage you to stop 
drinking alcohol and follow up with your primary care doctor as 
well as your chronic pain clinic. 

Another possible cause of your low blood pressure is something 
called "autonomic dysfunction." This can occur in people with 
HIV, and it is caused by a problem with the nerves that control 
your blood vessels and your blood pressure. We are recommending 
that you see a neurologist for testing to further evaluate this. 


It was a pleasure caring for you,
Your ___ Care Team

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF SUMMARY STATEMENT:  Ms. ___ is an ___ year old female 
with ___ CAD (s/p 6 stents), HTN, paroxysmal afib on coumadin 
and dronedarone, and aortic stenosis s/p porcine AVR ___ who 
presents with an episode from lightheadedness who was found (per 
report) to be with symptomatic bradycardia and hypotension. Pt. 
was without any repeat episodes of bradycardia or hypotension. 
Her lisinopril was held given low-normal BPs. She was noted to 
be in nearly continuous APC bigeminy/trigeminy pattern. It was 
thought that pt. was possibly pre-load dependent, may have been 
mildly hypovolemic resulting in symptomatic lightheadedness. We 
attempted to start pt. on beta blockade with metoprolol, however 
she refused given prior tolerance issues. We also noted pt. to 
be with infrequent paroxysmal runs of multifocal atrial 
tachycardia. For this, we began the pt. on low dose diltiazem to 
possibly help both conditions. She was discharged home with a 
___ of Heart's monitor and close cardiology follow-up.

Discharge Instructions:
Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure meeting and caring for you during your 
hospitalization.  You were admitted with lightheadedness and 
slow heart rate.  The slow heart rate was suspected by your home 
physical therapist.  We did not see evidence of a slow heart 
rate during your hospital stay.  We felt that your symptoms were 
related to dehydration and an ongoing abnormal heart rhythm 
called "ventricular bigeminy."  This is not a dangerous rhythm.  
You were also noted to have short periods of a fast abnormal 
heart rhythm.  You were started on a medication, diltiazem, to 
help your abnormal heart beat conditions.  In case your 
lisinopril was making your blood pressure too low, we stopped 
this medication at this time.

transmit information from the monitor to Dr. ___.  You will be

Brief Hospital Course:
___ male with a history of celiac disease, psoriasis, 
and hypertension who presents with sore throat for 1.5 weeks and 
painful rash for 4 days.

# Suspected erythema nodosum
The patient reported that on ___, he had new onset of a 
painful, nodular, erythematous rash. The rash first began on his 
right arm with a painful red nodule that later spread to the 
left arm, bilateral knees, bilateral shins, and bilateral bony 
prominences of the feet. The appearance of the rash is 
consistent with erythema nodosum, however, the presence of 
nodules on the arms was atypical. As a result, dermatology was 
consulted and performed a tissue biopsy, which showed findings 
consistent with erythema nodosum. Infectious workup was notable 
for negative hepatitis B serologies, negative HIV antibody, 
negative hepatitis C antibody, negative urine culture, negative 
Monospot, negative RPR, and unremarkable EBV serologies. Of 
note, Strep was pending at discharge a rheumatologic workup was 
also performed and was notable for a CRP of 100.3, borderline 
positive ___ (1: 40), negative ANCA. At the time of discharge, 
the patient's rash improved, and the pain from the rash was 
well-controlled with over-the-counter NSAIDs and acetaminophen. 
He was discharged with instructions to follow-up with 
dermatology pending formal tissue biopsy results.

# Sore throat
# Cough
The patient reported having about 2 weeks of sore throat 
associated with non-productive cough. Throughout his 
hospitalization, the patient had normal O2 saturations on room 
air. A chest x-ray performed in the emergency department did not 
show any evidence of pneumonia. On discharge, his sore throat 
was improved and his breathing remained at baseline. Etiology of 
the sore throat is most likely viral. Given that the sore throat 
preceded erythema nodosum, there was concern that the sore 
throat was caused by streptococcal pharyngitis. As a result, the 
patient received 2 g of ceftriaxone during his hospitalization. 
However, on ___, ceftriaxone was discontinued as it was 
determined that the patient had a very low risk of streptococcal 
pharyngitis given his age.

# Bilateral leg weakness
He has long-standing weakness that he reports is from previous 
back injuries. He was seen by physical therapy he felt that he 
was safe to go home without any more needs.

biopsy.

and erythema nodosum.

negative for vegetations. Ultimately it seems that the present 
illness is due to a recurrence of pyelonephritis. She was 
discharged on a prolonged course of Macrobid for a total of 
three weeks of treatment.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital because of 
worsening shortness of breath.  Your labs and chest x-ray showed 
no evidence of infection.  Your last CT image showed progression 
of your lung mass and obstruction of your airway.  You were 
evaluated by the Interventional Pulmonary team who placed a 
stent in your airway and performed a biopsy.

You will be going home with inhaled mucomyst.  Please make sure 
to do each treatment for as long as you can and to take deep 
breaths in and out during each treatment.  We also started you 
on pain medications while in the hospital.  You should not take 
these medications if you feel sleepy, with alcohol, or when 
operating any machinery.  Because these pain medications can 
cause constipation, you will also need to continue stool 
softeners when you return home.

Please follow-up with your outpatient providers as instructed 
below.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.  All best 
wishes for your recovery.

Sincerely,
Your ___ medical team

Ms. ___,

You were hospitalized after a fall.  You were admitted to the 
medicine service to evaluate cause of the fall, and workup

vasovagal syncope that can occur after using the bathroom.  In 
the future, please stand up slowly to avoid this happening 
again.

Because of the fall you sustained a spinal injury that required 
surgery with our orthopedics team.  You will follow up with the 
___ surgeons within the next two weeks following discharge 
from the hospital.

Please see below regarding the discharge instructions from the 
___ Surgeons.  

___ D/C Instructions:
Lumbar Decompression With Fusion:
You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
With Fusion
Immediately after the operation:
 Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks.You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
 Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: ___ times a day you should 
go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.You can 
walk as much as you can tolerate. Limit any kind of lifting.
 Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet.You may have some constipation 
after surgery.You have been given medication to help with this 
issue.
 Brace:You have been given a brace,this brace is to be worn 
when you are walking or out of bed. You may take it off while 
lying in bed.
 Wound Care:Keep the dressing in place until your follow up 
appointment. You may take a shower with this dressing. Please do 
not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If the incision begins 
to drain at any time, please call the ___. 
Follow up: Please Call the office and make an appointment for 2 
weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been done 
already. At the 2-week visit we will check your incision,take 
baseline X-rays and answer any questions.We may at that time 
start physical therapy. We will then see you at 6 weeks from the 
day of the operation and at that time release you to full 
activity.

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your 
hospitalization! We wish you all the best!

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team

water and soap in the shower.

care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was seen in clinic and admitted for sternal 
debridement. On ___ he underwent sternal debridement and 
during the procedure the LIMA was transected. The sternum was 
left open and the patient went immediately to the cath lab from 
the OR.  He was found to have native LAD disease but he was not 
stented because he was going to need further OR procedures, 
including pectoralis flaps, and it would have been problematic 
to have the pt. on Plavix.
His was treated with Vanco/Meropenem/Micafungin and Tobramycin. 
He went for a sternal washout on ___ and required some PRBC 
after the procedure. On ___ he was having ventricular 
arrhythmias which were treated with Lido and Amiodorone.  He was 
progressively acidotic over the day and had a rising lactate. He 
was seen by EP and the interventional cardiologists.  ___ he 
required a bicarb gtt and his lactate was rising despite volume. 
He underwent an exploratory laparotomy which was negative. When 
he was being moved from the OR table to the bed he coded and was 
shocked and had ROSC. He was then taken to the cath lab and had 
a stent placed to the LAD.  He again became unstable in the cath 
lab and had VT which resolved with epi.
He was transferred back to the CVICU and continued to 
deteriorate. He required increased pressors and went up to 0.6 
of levo, 0.2 of epi, and was also on maximum doses of 
vasopressin and neo.  
His family was present for most of the day and Dr. ___ them 
fully informed. He remained on multiple drips and CRRT was 
started.  He did not improve and since the cath lab his pupils 
were fixed and dilated.
He became asystolic at 3:35 on ___ and had no blood pressure. 
The family and Dr. ___ informed of the patient's demise. 
The family did not want an autopsy and the medical examiner 
declined the case.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o gentleman with a past medical history significant for 
Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 (last A1c-13), mild 
chronic kidney disease, Hyperlipidemia, Coronary Artery Disease 
s/p drug eluting stent to right coronary and left circumflex who 
comes in with 4 day history of scrotal pain and tenderness.
.
#Testicular pain/swelling
Admitted overnight on ___ with complaints of marked scrotal 
tenderness and erythema. Patient was afebrile with stable vital 
signs. His exam showed erythema over scrotal skin as well as 
erythematous skin within his groin folds bilaterally. WBC was 
11.1. There was concern for a deeper perineal infection, so 
General Surgery and Urology were consulted. Based on these 
services' recommendations, the patient was initially started on 
empiric antibiotic therapy with vancomycin, zosyn, & 
clindamycin. However, a CT pelvis showed no signs of necrotizing 
fascitis, and with low suspicion for fournier's gangrene, the 
zosyn and clindamycin were discontinued. He received a 1 time 
dose of 2mg IV morphine for pain control, but by the following 
morning, was no longer having any pain or tenderness to 
palpation. Further, his WBC count had normalized. He was felt to 
have a topical fungal infection with possibly an associated 
cellulitis. Given the clinical improvement, we discharged the 
patient home on PO bactrim DS BID 7-day course and miconazole 
cream bid. Patient was encouraged to maintain good perineal 
hygiene and to take tylenol for potential perineal discomfort. 
Blood and urine cultures are negative to date. He will f/u in 
___ clinic on ___.
.
#. HTN: 
Given uncertainty of infection and possible susceptibility to 
hemodynamic compromise home antihypertensives was initially 
held. Patient remained normotensive throughout hospital course. 
.
#. DM2/Hyperglycemia: 
Patient reports a recent hospitalization at ___ for elevated 
glucose to 800. He is followed at the ___ and ___ glargine 
at home. In the hospital, his finger sticks ranged from 140s to 
low 200s.
.

.
#. Thigh rash:

excoriation-related although could not exclude leukocytoclastic 
vasculitis. Improving without intervention per patient and can 
be followed up as outpatient.

Brief Hospital Course:
IMPRESSION: ___ with a PMH significant for ulcerative colitis 
and remote history of migraine headache who presented with 
headache and transient vision changes found to be hypertensive 
to 200/100 mmHg with reassuring CTA head and neck imaging 
concerning for hypertensive urgency vs. emergency.
.
# HYPERTENSIVE URGENCY VS. EMERGENCY - The patient presented 
with a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg on routine PCP ___ 
1-month ago with no prior history of hypertension, certainly a 
prior history of uncontrolled essential hypertension is 
plausible. She has few modifiable risk factors, she is not 
obese, denies excessive alcohol intake, and is physically active 
with aerobic activity. She is not on anti-hypertensive 
medications and recently discontinued her OCP (Aviane). Her 
blood pressure has ranged from ___ mmHg over 2-days 
with symptoms of posterior headache and neck pain, involuntary 
muscle spasm vs. distal extremity parathesias and twitching as 
well as transient vision concerns - despite normal renal 
function, no cardiac ischemic changes on EKG, encephalopathy, 
papilledema or retinal hemorrhaging. Given this symptomatology, 
hypertensive emergency was the concern. Overall her work-up was 
reassuring with a negative head and neck CTA and negative head 
MR imaging. She also had a reasurring laboratory work-up, 
although her EKG did show some chronic LVH changes and 
ultimately we attributed her condition to undiagnosed and 
uncontrolled essential hypertension. A Labetalol gtt was started 
in the ED and she was quickly weaned to PO Labetalol and then 
started Lisinopril 10 mg PO daily which will continue as an 
outpatient. She will follow-up with her PCP ___ 1-week for 
electrolyte monitoring.
.
# NECK SPASM, CERVICAL DYSTONIA - The patient presented with 
features of right neck and shoulder pain that has occurred 
before, per her daughter. The physical exam findings and 
clinical history indicate a primary focal dystonia or cervical 
dystonia. Half of patients describe pain in the setting of these 
findings. Her CTA did note some degenerative changes with disc 
space narrowing and disc-osteophyte complexes at C4/5, ___, and 
___ but the symptomatology seemed unrelated. This likely 
represents a separate process from her hypertensive urgency and 
there is no evidence of a medication-induced effect. She 
responded to Tylenol and PRN Valium with symptomatic relief.
.
# ULCERATIVE COLITIS - History of ulcerative colitis that has 
been left-colon predominant diagnosed in ___. She has had prior 
flares a few times yearly with rectal bleeding and last 
sigmoidoscopy in ___ showed left-sided colitis only. She has 
never been on corticosteroid treatment. She was previously on 
5-ASA (Rewasa) therapy only intermittently. She has no active 
rectal bleeding or abdominal pain symptoms to suggest active 
flare.
.
TRANSITION OF CARE ISSUES:
1. Follow-up scheduled with PCP ___ 1-week with electrolyte 
monitoring.

Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or 
wheezing.
* You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids, or your 
medications.
* If you are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include: dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit, or have a 
bowel movement.
* You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
* Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under 
control within 24 hours.
* Your pain worsens or changes location.
* You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with a DVT (deep venous thrombosis) of your 
right lower extremity.  It was determined that based on your 
physical exam and ct scan, a surgical thrombolytic therapy would 
not be beneficial at this time.  

You will be discharged on anticoagulation for 6 months. You will 
go home on Lovenox injections and oral coumadin therapy.  
Coumadin therapy required frequent blood draws to check the INR 
(international normalized ratio).  Your PCP, ___ be 
following this for you and adjust your coumadin dose as needed.  
Once the INR is 2.0 or greater you will be able to stop your 
lovenox injections.  The goal INR is 2.0-3.0 .  You should take 
your coumadin at the same time every day and tell your PCP if 
you take antibiotics at any time during the course of therapy. 

You have also been given a thigh high ___ stocking to wear on 
your right leg.  You should wear this daily until your follow up 
appointment with the vascular surgeon.  

You may resume normal daily activities such as walking, and 
driving. Do not drive while taking narcotic medications. You 
will need to elevate your right leg, above the level of your 
heart as much as possible over the next few weeks.  

Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. 
* Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or 
feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your skin, or the whites of your eyes become yellow.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication.  You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.  
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
