Brief Hospital Course:
Legal: ___
Psychiatric:
Patient presented in disorganized state, exhibiting symptoms of 
pressured speech, tangential behavior, elevated mood, SIB 
(slapped self), and hypersexuality. Patient also had notable 
cognitive deficits, particularly in memory (note patient has 
already had formal Neuro-Psych testing in ___ which showed 
gross executive functional impairment of unknown etiology). 
Patient evaluated medically in the unit for other underlying 
organic causes (see below), but no significant organic 
explanation of symptoms. 

Upon admission medications were: Clonezepam 0.5 mg QHS, 
Lamotrigine 200 mg PO QHS, Trazodone 75 mg PO HS, Venlafaxine 
150 mg PO daily, Zolpidem tartrate 10 mg PO HS. We continued 
Lamotrigine 200 mg PO QHS, discontinued the trazadone and 
zolpidem tartarate and discontinued venlafaxine via a gradual 
taper. We initiated and tapered quietapine up to 150 mg QHS and 
held steady at this dose. We initially tapered and discontinued 
Clonezepam but due to patient report nightly panic attacks we 
restarted Clonezepam 0.5 mg QHS, with good effect and subsequent 
dramatic improvement in sleep.

With medication adjustments and individual, group, and milieu 
therapy, the patient slowly and steadily improved. With a 
significant improvement in her degree of mood lability, 
organization, and degree of disinhibition. Her insight into her 
condition and judgement also significantly improved. Her panic 
attacks resolved and her sleep also greatly improved.  At no 
point during her hospitalization did she demonstrate suicidal 
thoughts or self injury. She was always cooperative and help 
seeking. 

By the time of discharge the patient's acute mania resolved and 
appeared close to her baseline. She participated appropriately 
with her peers and in groups.  She is able to dress herself, 
groom, and take regular showers. Her gait has improved 
dramatically, at times needed reminders to use her cane early on 
in admission. By time of discharge, she demonstrated good safety 
awareness and care when changing positions. She was not 
orthostatic by frequent vital sign checks. The patient exhibited 
no self-injurious behavior while hospitalized nor did she voice 
any intent to harm herself during this hospitalization. Ms. 
___ is stable to go home to a supervised environment that 
___ can provide in addition to structure provided by a 
day treatment program. She will continue to have regular follow 
up by her outpatient providers.       
 
Medical:
#) Neurological workup: CT Head ordered by team showed enlarged 
ventricles and evidence of hypodensities indicating some small 
vessel ischemic disease but no gross abnormality. Patient had 
laboratories (CBC, electrolytes) which were within normal 
limits. UA showed +WBC but no nitrates.

#) Nutrition/Weight Loss: Nutrition consult revealed patient is 
low nutrition risk. Diet supplemented with ensure in unit. 
Patient to follow up with PCP for further evaluation for medical 
causes of weight loss. Patient ate all of her meals during her 
hospitalization without difficulty. 

#) Hair loss: Patient reported hair loss over the past ~6 
months. Initial ___ including CBC, BMP, TSH, B12, Folate was 
negative for a revealing etiology. The patient showed no 
evidence of self inflicted hair loss during hospitalization. 
Patient instructed to follow-up with her PCP for further ___ 
of her hair loss. 

#) Fall risk: ___ assessment determined patient is a low fall 
risk but encouraged patient to use cane at all times for safety. 
Patient was able to follow these recommendations well by the end 
of her hospitalization 

#) Orthostasis: Patient initially experienced orthostasis early 
on during hospitalization when her seroquel was being titrated, 
this resolved and she tolerated 150mg seroquel well by time of 
dischagre. . 

#) Sacral Folliculitis: Evaluated by wound nurse in hospital. 
Dressing placed. Per wound nurse evaluation, does not appear to 
be related to picking behavior or prolonged sitting. The patient 
remained appropriately mobile and active through out 
hospitaization. Patient to follow-up with PCP.

#) Borderline UA: Urine culture was likely contaminated but 
positive for gardinella. Patient denied any symptoms of vaginal 
discharge or pain. No symptoms of dysuria. As a result, there 
was no further follow-up or treatment.

Family/Social Work: Patient lives at a ___, a facility 
without nighttime care but nursing and staff throughout the day. 
She also enjoys attending a geriatric day program. Her care was 
coordinated with her children by socialwork and the patient 
remained in frequent contact with them through out her stay. 
___ house was also coordinated with at time of discharge. 
Initally requesting transfer to rehab, but ultimately accepting 
her transfer back to them. 

Groups/Milieu: Patient enjoyed attending groups, particularly 
music therapy. Adjusted well to milieu. 

Risk Assessment: At no point during her hospitalization was self 
injury or suicidality an active clinical concern. The patient 
always expressed enthusiasm for her life and her family. Given 
her history of bipolar disorder, there is some chronic risk 
through time of suicidality or self injury. However this risk is 
reduced now that her mood has been stabilized and she continues 
to have ongoing structure and support outside of the hospital. 
Currently the patient is a low to moderate fall risk due to her 
history of orthostasis and recent falls prior to her 
hospitalization, however she is currently  ambulating well with 
a w cane and is conscious of need to take her time in standing 
up and adjust from dizziness. She demonstated a good awareness 
of this through out her hospitalization. Currently, there is no 
evidence of inability to care for herself in her current 
supported living situation.

Discharge Instructions:
You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from 
your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST  refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.
 
 
Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
have any of the following:
 
 * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
 tightness.
 
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
 medications.
 
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
 diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
 mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
 
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
 

* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
 degrees or 38(C) degrees.
 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
 concern you. 
 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
 as ordered.

prevent pulling or dislocation.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to Medicine service after having 
two episodes of bright red blood per rectum.
.
# GI bleeding: This bleeding was thought to be most likely from 
the distal GI tract given the description of bright red blood 
and the absence of epigastric pain, nausea or hematemesis. He 
was given IV fluid on the day of admission. His antihypertensive 
medications were held. He was evaluated by Gastrointestinal 
service who recommended colonoscopy and 
esophagogastroduodenoscopy especially because the patient has 
never had colonoscopy in the past and he has a history of 
chronic anemia. Colonoscopy revealed three benign-appearing, 
non-bleeding polyps, one in the transverse colon, and two in the 
ascending colon. There was no evidence of new or recent 
bleeding. Capsule endoscopy is recommended as further work up, 
to be done by the patient's PCP as outpatient.He did not have 
any further episodes of bleeding after he was admitted to 
Medicine survice. His hematocrit remained stable during this 
admission. Metroprolol 12.5 mg BID was resumed on the day of 
disposition. Other antihypertensive medications were stopped. 
The patient is to be followed up by his PCP, ___ on 
___.
.
# Normocytic anemia: The patient was found to have chronic 
anemia which has not been investigated as far as the patient's 
awared. His B12 and folate levels were both normal. Iron studies 
suggested that there may be a component of anemia of chronic 
disease. Acute bleeding would not totally account for this 
especially given that only a small to moderate amount of blood 
was noted with his bowel movements. The plan to further evaluate 
GI bleeding is capsule endoscopy as discussed above.
.  
# Coag-positive S. aureus UTI: Prior to this admission, the 
patient has already been treated with a full course of 
fluroquinolone (Ciprofloxacin followed by Levofloxacin). His 
urinalysis on admission was negative. He remained afebrile. His 
blood culture had NGTD at discharge.
.
# Elevated ESR and CRP: ESR is 108 (was 60 in ___ and ___, 
CRP 89.8 (CRP was 4 in ___. Differential diagnoses of elevated 
ESR and CRP include inflammation, infection or malignancy. 
Causes could be recent UTI, bacteremia, autoimmune processes or 
malignancy. PSA level was checked and was normal (0.1). ESR and 
CRP should be repeated at follow-up visit with Dr. ___.
.
# Transaminitis: AST 81-82, ALT 52-56. Last ALT in ___ was 
normal. Simvastatin was held on the day of admission. Tylenol 
level was checked, which was negative. Hepatitis serologies are 
pending at the time of disposition. His only new medication was 
levofloxacin, which may cause transaminis, but less likely in 
this case because AST and ALT levels remained elevated after he 
finished the course of antibiotic. The patient denied recent 
alcohol use. Other differential diagnoses include non-alcoholic 
fatty liver disease, infectious, malignant or metastatic 
processes. LFTs should be repeated in ~1 week by his PCP as 
outpatient.
.
# Elevated direct bilirubin: Patient was found to have elevated 
direct bilirubin of 0.4, concerning for cholestatic proceses. On 
exam, he was afebrile and there was no RUQ or abdominal 
tenderness to palpation. No jaundice noted. RUQ ultrasound was 
obtained which showed fatty liver and gallstones but no evidence 
of inflammation or cholestasis. 
.
# Bilateral leg pain: Chronic issue. He was kept on dilaudid prn 
pain. His pain was well-controlled during this admission.
.
# Hypertension: Antihypertensive medications were held on the 
day of admission for GI bleeding and because patient was 
normotensive. His blood pressures during this admission ranged 
from 120-140's/60-70's. On disposition, only metoprolol was 
resumed with dose changed to 12.5 mg BID.  
.
# Right ankle pain: The patient developed ankle pain over the 
right medial malleolus. He reported that he has had many 
episodes of acute "gout" attacks in the past that lasted about 
___ days, the last episode happend about ___ years ago. He denied 
having had arthrocentesis. He reported that he went to the ED 
last time he had this type of pain but was told there was no 
treatment for his condition. He reported having had similar pain 
in both ankles and on the bottom of his feet several years ago. 
On exam, he was afebrile. There was minimal erythema over the 
right medial malleolus that was moderately tender to palpation 
and with passive range of movement. No swelling appreciated. 
Gout in differential. Patient already has a follow-up 
appointment with his PCP the day after disposition. In the 
meantime, he is instructed to take pain regimen as prescribed 
and to apply ice pack as needed.

#Acute on chronic kidney injury: 
Patient with baseline creatinine of ~1.5. Was 1.7 post procedure 
on ___ AM and bumped to 2.1 on ___ AM. Acute kidney injury was 
thought to be pre-renal in etiology given FeNa calculated to 
0.23%. Held home furosemide and enalapril. Received fluid 
boluses with NS and administration of Albumin 25% (12.5g / 50mL) 
50 g IV. Improved to 1.8 at time of discharge. 
 
# Temperature: Patient spiked temperature to 102.1 on ___ ___ 
with associated leukocytosis to 13.5 in AM ___. No localizing 
signs or symptoms and patient denied cough/dysuria. UA with few 
bacteria and negative leuk esterase/nitrites and was felt to be 
asymptomatic bacteruria. Differential diagnosis included post-op 
atelectasis versus RFA post ablation syndrome versus portal vein 
thrombosis given concomitant elevation in LFTs and ___ 
(described above). RUQ Doppler US performed with no evidence of 
portal vein thrombosis. No further febrile episodes and 
leukocytosis resolved ___ thus likely secondary to resolving 
atelectasis versus RFA post ablation syndrome.

# Urinary retention: Patient with urinary retention following 
procedure on ___. Felt to be secondary to anesthetic/opioid 
(oxycodone) effect. Required straight cath for 800 cc 1AM ___ 
and was straight cath'd for another 550cc at 3PM ___. 
Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO DAILY started ___ and low dose Tylenol 
added prn (max 2g/day given liver disease) to try to reduce 
amount of oxycodone required. Subsequently with improved 
urination on his own. Discharged on Tamsulosin. 

# ___ s/p RFA: Per ___, procedure itself went well but was 
subsequently complicated by transient, asymptomatic bradycardia. 
Patient with similar episode following TACE in ___. During 
that admission, patient was evaluated by EP who felt vasovagal 
in etiology. Was monitored on telemetry with no alarms for 
bradycardia. Pain controlled with Tylenol and oxycodone.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was our pleasure caring for you during your hospital stay at 
___. 

You were admitted to the hospital after your RFA procedure due 
to some episodes of low heart rates during the procedure and 
because you were feeling dizzy after the procedure. We monitored 
you on the cardiac monitor and noted no additional periods of 
low heart rates. 

You had some difficulty urinating after the procedure that we 
think was due to a combination of the anesthesia and the pain 
killers (oxycodone) you were receiving. We started you on a new 
medication called tamsulosin that can help with difficulty 
urinating and that you should continue as an outpatient. We also 
gave you low dose Tylenol to decrease the amount of oxycodone 
you required for pain control. At the time of discharge, you 
were urinating on your own without difficulty. 

You additionally spiked a temperature while you were in the 
hospital but we did not detect any signs of infection. We think 
that the temperature may have been due to "atelectasis" or 
improper inflation of portions of your lung (a normal occurrence 
after procedures requiring anesthesia) or potentially due to the 
inflammation caused by the RFA procedure. We performed an 
ultrasound of your liver and we did not see anything concerning. 
You had no temperature and were breathing well on room air at 
the time of your discharge. 

Finally, your kidney function was a little worse following the 
procedure. We think that this was due to dehydration and it 
improved with the fluids and albumin we gave you.  We held your 
home Enalapril and Furosemide (Lasix) as these can affect your 
kidney function.  You should not restart these until you have 
your labs checked by your primary care physician at your next 
appointment.

You should follow up with your primary care physician and liver 
team after you leave the hospital. 

We wish you the best! 
Your ___ Care Team
